title: brexit latest theresa may brussels showdown donald tusk
story: The PM fronted up the EU boss and told him his outrageous comments were not helpful and caused widespread dismay in the UK.After talks with several EU leaders today she told reporters before heading back to Britain: Ive raised with President Tusk the language that he used yesterday, which is not helpful and caused widespread dismay in the United Kingdom.Mr Tusk sparked uproar by saying there was a place in hell reserved for Brexiteers who campaigned to leave without a plan.Now the PM said that talks will start to find a way to get this over the line and push her deal through the Commons.She vowed: I am clear that I am going to deliver Brexit, I am going to deliver it on time.I will be negotiating hard in the coming days to do just that.On her way in to the EU headquarters the PMs convoy was interrupted by a Europhile protester, who threw himself in front of a car in an apparent bid to stop her.But she later got some better news as she convinced the EU to back down and hold more talks on the hated Northern Irish border.After a robust showdown with EU boss Jean Claude Juncker today, she managed to secure an extra three weeks of discussions on the UKs future relationship with the bloc.Mrs May insisted the UK must not be trapped in the hated Northern Ireland backstop and laid out a string of options to get out of the mess.The two leaders agreed that their teams should hold talks as to whether a way through can be found, a statement released from No said.Although Mr Juncker insisted the Withdrawal Agreement cannot be changed, he expressed his openness to edit the UKs future relationship with the EU to get to a deal quicker.No described the news as important progress today.But Mr Tusk warned that other EU leaders would have to agree to it too.The pair will meet again before the end of February to take stock, officials confirmed today, kicking the can for securing a deal even further down the road towards exit day in March.EU Parliament Antonio Tajani told reporters after separate talks with Mrs May that the EU would be more ambitious on our future relations, including looking at the Irish situation againthe UKs red lines change.But he warned: We are very concerned. Were weeks away from an economic and human catastrophe.The PM told the EUs Guy Verhofstadt that she wasnt seeking to rip up the backstop at all - which could risk the rage of Brexiteer MPs who demanded she find a whole new solution.But Mr Verhofstadt said they could upgrade the political declaration, making it more binding, more precise.And he admitted that leaving without a deal would hit the EU too - saying it would be a disaster on both sides of the channel.The Sun revealed last night that the PM is set to scrap the plan for Tory unity - the so-called Plan C - now EU leaders have shot it down.Allies say Mrs May knew beforehand that EU leaders will never accept it and wants to swtly move on over the weekend to pressing for legally binding changes to toughen up the current backstop.Instead of re-opening the deal, Brussels might allow a legally binding letter to make it clear that the hated backstop deal is only temporary, The Times reported today.This morning Jeremy Corbyn threatened to derail the talks by hinting that Labour could back a soft Brexit.He wrote to the PM laying out the conditions which his party would back a deal.Meanwhile, No last night played down the prospect of getting a breakthrough in time to put to MPs in next Thursday’s Commons votes.A senior Downing Street source said: “If the clouds clear then great, but realistically it’s not where we’re going.”The source added that the Government would have to put “something” down to vote on next Thursday but said he expects the “focus” will be on other amendments such as attempts to legislate against a no deal Brexit.Delaying the votes further will ramp up the pressure from Remainers to extend Article  to allow enough time to get all the legislation through the House of Commons in time.

title: jeremy corbyn closet brexiteer ignores second referendum letter may
story: The leftie leader wrote to the PM saying hell back hershe tacks towards a soft Brexit plan.But he failed to mention a second referendum - despite Labours policy that a fresh vote on Brexit should be considered.Remainers blasted Mr Corbyn over his letter - saying it shows he secretly DOES want Britain to quit the EU despite his previous pledges.Today Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer scrambled to repair the damage, insisting: It does not take the option of a public vote off the table.The Labour boss told the PM last night he was ready to open talks on what it would take for the party to back her Brexit deal.He wrote: Following last week’s rejection by the House of Commons of No Deal, all necessary steps must be taken to avoid such an outcome.My colleagues and I look forward to discussing these proposals with you further, in the constructive manner in which they are intended.Mr Corbyn called for a permanent and comprehensive customs union with the EU - which would stop Britain cutting its own trade deals.The other four demands called for close co-operation over goods rules, workers rights, Europe-wide agencies and security.But there was no reference to a so-called peoples vote despite previous claims that Labour would back a second referendumit failed to force a General Election.Remainer ringleader Chuka Umunna blasted: I hate to think what all those young voters who flocked to the party for the first time in  will make of this.Vote Labour, get a Tory Brexit. They will feel they have been sold down the river.Former leadership contender Owen Smith added: Backing Brexit - even on these terms - would still shrink our economy, cost jobs and lost investment, indulge nativist nostalgia and isolationism... and pave the way for another austerity Tory Government.He even hinted he could quit the party in protest.And Pat McFadden suggested the letter was a signal to Labour MPs that they wont be punishedthey side with Mrs May on Brexit.Second referendum campaigners attacked Mr Corbyn for ignoring his own partys policy, which states that a peoples vote should be an option.Lib Dem Tom Brake said: After  years sitting on the backbenches arguing for more power for members and against the EU, Corbyn has finally chosen to go for the latter at the expense of the former.And Eloise Todd, CEO of the Best for Britain campaign, said: Labour must push the Tories harder to take no deal off the table and then give the public the final say on Brexit.Mrs Mays deputy David Lidington agreed to meet with Labour frontbenchers in a bid to break the Brexit deadlock.Mr Corbyn has pursued a deliberately vague policy on the EU in a bid to avoid alienating either wing of his ided party.But recent polls suggest young Remainers are losing patience with the refusal to commit to an anti-Brexit stance.

title: labour lose votes brexit remainers desert corbyn
story: Jeremy Corbyns failure to back a second referendum could be far more damaging than the Iraq war, according to a leading trade union.It comes as young EU enthusiasts turn against Labour in protest against Mr Corbyns Brexit policy.The damning poll findings come in a document commissioned by the TSSA union, which asked YouGov to carry out a nationwide survey.The results, leaked to ITV News, suggest Labour would pick up votesit supported a second referendum on the EU.They concluded: There can be no disguising the sense of disappointment and disillusionment with Labourit fails to oppose Brexit and there is every indication that it will be far more damaging to the partys electoral fortunes than the Iraq war.Labour would especially lose the support of people below the age of , which could make this issue comparable to to impact the tuition fees and involvement in coalition had on Lib Dem support.The dossier suggests that nearly half of Labour voters may switch their vote to a new centrist partyit pledged to oppose Brexit.In a snap election where Labour backed Britain quitting the EU, it would lose an estimated  seats - leaving the party nowhere near power.Under Tony Blair, Labour shed more than million votes in the wake of the Iraq war.And the Lib Dems lost .million supporters during the coalition years amid fury at their support for university tuition fees.Today Mr Corbyn angered Remainer MPs by offering to work with Theresa May to pass a Brexit deal - instead of backing a second referendum.

title: danny dyer right royal family flaw
story: A documentary that was as funny as it was surprising, and all the more so because the BBC did the right thing and played it absolutely straight.Genuine blue plaque television, in fact, that should never have been revisited or reformatted, not least because it would remind the Beeb that Danny’s wonderful everyman story had killed the whole WDYTYA franchise.So I’d been expecting this sucker punch, ever since its final credits rolled in .Danny Dyer’s Right Royal Family, on BBC. “A potty old adventure,” as his nibs described it, tracing Danny’s family line even further back, to Scandinavia’s King Rollo, his -times great grandfather, who I’d always assumed was a s children’s cartoon character, rather than a ninth-century Viking warrior.There were two episodes of it this time as well, which I know some of you thought were as funny as the original. Personally, I didn’t.What I hope we’re all agreed on, though, is the fact that Danny’s too busy playing Danny Dyer, the professional geezer, to be a good listener or natural TV historian.It’s an act that worked, of course, when he was wondering, “Eleanor of Aquitaine, was she a looker ” but didn’t serve him so well when presented with a longbow.“Long, innit ”The Beeb clocked this before production started, obviously, so had paired him up with dozens of head-patting historians and actors who got him to dress up as every kind of medieval t**t you can imagine. Like Mr Benn on crack, it was.Armour, codpieces, nappies, tights, doublet and hose, and a gigantic white smock, bleached with human urine, which had one grovelling “courtier” wondering: “Has all the p*** been washed out, my Lord King ”A good question.We didn’t actually get the answer, though, until part two, on Wednesday, when, after a brief detour round his ancestors, Louis IX of France, William the Conqueror and Henry II, viewers got to the nub of things, with Professor Chris Given-Wilson explaining the agonising death of Edward II: “By thrusting a hollow instrument, like the end of a trumpet, up his fundament.”“’Old on a minute,” said a rattled Danny. “He’s been stabbed  With a trumpet ”“Into his fundament.” Long pause.“Don’t tell me it’s up his a**e ”Right up it, Danny, with a red-hot poker. News which didn’t just do his “nut in”, it seemed to derail the entire documentary.They ran out of direct royal ancestors shortly afterwards as well, and the BBC adopted its stupid default setting in such circumstances. It turned Danny’s Right Royal Family into a dance and cookery show, complete with demonstrations of both, from medieval experts.It was about this time I also sussed out what was going on in the background, with all those winsome historians. An audition.The BBC was using it to find its new face of history, though why any of the blokes turned up is a mystery. Auntie’s already made it clear: “The days of white, middle-aged men explaining stuff are over.”Danny, on the other hand, can be tolerated, because he’s their new performing Cockney. A novelty act who can be dressed up and patronised so much he ended this one doing some weird medieval can-can, with his family, in front of his lost ancestral pile.A trumpet wasn’t quite shoved up his fundament as they danced, but the p*** had very much been washed out of him, my Lord King.GREAT TV lies and delusions of the month. “I think it’s going to be a really great show.” Cheryl Tweedy, The Greatest Dancer.“We do TV shows and we’re national treasures.” Jedward, Celebrity Coach Trip.“People will remember my name and I love that.” Some t**t off Ship- wrecked.IF you’re to take anything from the news experts have claimed Monday, January  was the most depressing day of the year, it’s probably the fact the experts clearly never sat through what happened eight days later, on Tuesday, January .Britain’s Top  Dogs Live: . All two-and-a-half yapping hours of it, on ITV, with a bad hangover, in the company of presenters Ben Fogle and Sara Cox.A test beyond personal endurance not because of the alcohol or dogs, who are a largely blameless lot, but the presence of their barmy owners, who attribute all sorts of superpowers to their dumb little mutts and blur the human animal relationship way beyond the point of reason and sometimes even good taste.Hits Radio DJ Gemma Atkinson, for instance, claimed: “I wouldn’t be where I am today without Norman”, her pet sproodle.Which is a hell of a guilt trip to pin on any dog.While Spandau Ballet’s Martin Kemp was seen, sitting alongside Popsie the poodle and his Wham! backing-singer we Shirlie, exclaiming: “I’ll say this for her,she does do a poo she goes into the spare bathroom.”The least you’d expect, frankly, after  years of marriage.The case study that really finished me off, though, was a dog dancing instructor called Joan Clark and her powder puff hounds, whose act, as described by Sara Cox, was: “All building up to the big finish. Can she pull it off  Joan points to the spot and it’s one, two, three pups between her legs.”CHANNEL ’s Pure is a comedy drama about a woman who suffers from the sixth sense of seeing naked people and is so tormented by her condition she screams: “F***ing stop. Make it stop.”So she can read minds as well.QUIZ show doughballs of the week. The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Real Madrid play their home football matches in which Spanish city ”John: “Barcelona.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which month of the year was named after the Roman Emperor Augustus ”Jorge: “July.”Ben Shephard: “Hajduk Split are a football team from which eastern European country ”Jenner: “Japan.”And Joe Lycett: “In his song Le On Mars, David Bowie wonderedthere was le on which planet ”Amber: “Jupiter.” Andy Murray texting Good Morning Britain with the :am request: “Please stop discussing my genitals on national television.”Andrew Neil ripping all of Ken Livingstone’s socialist fantasies about Venezuela into tiny shreds, on This Week.And The Time It Takes answer contestant John gave to the question: “The metaphorical breaking of which body part brings good luck to an actor ” “Neck.” A thought that’s occurred to me every time I watch the Baftas.FAIR play, I thought, to Vagisan feminine itching cream and Jenny Eclair. They really seemed to have all the important ITV advertising bases covered.First thing in the morning they’re dropping regular hints about “bothersome vaginas” during Piers Morgan’s Good Morning Britain sht. Then there they were again, on Sunday night, directly before Gemma Collins skated at Dancing On Ice.Although, I say “skated,” you’d see marginally more movement from the Larsen C ice shelf in Antarctica than we got from Gemma on this week’s show.The heroic Matt Evers had to shove, heave, prod and generally wield her like a hypermarket shopping trolley, in fact, just to get Gemma turning on her axis.One very calculated burst of tears later, though, the mug punters had voted her through for yet another week and she’d parked her over-entitled backside on Piers Morgan’s sofa early yesterday morning.So where the hell was Vagisan feminine itching cream and Jenny Eclair when the occasion really called for them Asleep on the job, that’s where. Call yourself a “relief” GREAT Sporting Insights. Martin Keown: “Abramovich has spent £.billion at Cha. That’s £million per championship.”Jermaine Jenas: “The ball misses Trippier’s head by a second.”John Inverdale: “Warren Gatland began his reign  years ago to the day, tomorrow.”And Paul Merson: “Petr Cech was a great shop spotter.”Sent in by Tom Baxter, Denny, Stirlingshire. Picture research Jimbo.RANDOM TV irritations: The widespread but mistaken belief that “you just can’t have too much Romesh Ranganathan”.The Voice UK audience member who shouted: “Olly, I think you should sing.” Jonathan Davies’ complete inability to keep his Welsh bias out of the rugby commentary box.ITV’s Small Fortune already looking like the worst game show of the year.  And catchphrase-chasing hosts Alesha Dixon and Jordan Banjo declaring, “Things are getting really seri-arse”, on The Greatest Dancer, just at the point things were getting even more tedi-arse.TV OBSERVATION round. Who said the following last week “It looks like it’s dragging its legs on the floor, doing a hip wiggle. But it’s actually scent-marking with its anal glands, on the side of a track, on the side of a road, anywhere a passing male might snf it.”A Iolo Williams on Winterwatch’s pine marten B Sam Matterface on Dancing On Ice’s Gemma Collins Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: people tissue thin slice away
story: NewsPeople are a tissue thin slice away from disaster: Homeless mans warning to us allWe spoke to homeless people at Encompass Southwest in Barnstaple, Devon, as part of our Mirror On The Street investigation into rough sleepingShareByAdam Aspinall:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsRichards relationship breakdown led him to ruin and he has never quite recovered "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHomelessness can strike anyone, at anytime. That was the message The Daily Mirror learned on a visit to a breakfast club for rough sleepers this week. Never more was this in evidence then -year-old Richard. Once a respected news reporter on a local paper it seemed he had the world at his feet. But like so many homeless people a relationship breakdown led him to ruin and he has never quite recovered. He has lived on and off the streets ever since. He said: “People are a tissue thin slice away from disaster, they just don’t think about it.” Richard, who along with others in this article did not wish to give his full name, was just one of many vulnerable adults and young people who wandered in and out of the breakfast club organised by independent homeless charity Encompass Southwest, based in Barnstaple, Devon.  The charity has gone from a tiny soup kitchen in  to employing  full and part-time members of staff who provide a range of service to tough sleepers in North Devon from advice, to support services and housing. One of the many services Encompass offer rough sleepers is a popular breakfast club every Tuesday morning in the spare room of a local radio station. Manned by staff and volunteers at least  rough sleepers came and went from am until noon all with ying stories to tell but all just thankful for a warm breakfast. The age range was shocking, the youngest was  and the eldest , from a wide iety of walks of le. Frightened Will, , revealed he was kicked out of his house by his parents and has slept rough for five months. He says there are lots of people who try to take advantage of him so admitted he has carried a weapon in the past to feel safe. He said: “It’s a nightmare out there, people will abuse youthey can so you have to be wary, I’m just focusing on getting out of this situation the best way I can.”  Gavin, , said he used to be able earn as much pound a day when he ran his own tiling business but a relationship break-up saw him lose everything. He now sleeps in a park which he describes as “scary”. He said people need to understand that “homelessness can happen to anyone, at anytime.” Amongst the many cheerful volunteers was humble AE nurse Sarah Gabe, . She volunteers at the breakfast club every week and admitted it took some time to win the rough sleeper’s trust but now she can use of her medical skills to treat them directly.  She said: “It took about six months for them to trust me to the point where they now come to me with problems. “It is mainly simple things like foot care and listening to their chests but when you are sleeping rough small things can become big problems so it is great that I can see them directly and help them where I can.”  One rough sleeper at the breakfast club who has definitely benefited from Encompass’s hands-on approach is -year-old Paul. Originally from London he explained he drted out to Devon because it was “safer” but a mixture of drink and drug problems have kept him on the streets ever since. He is what homelessness experts describe as ‘entrenched’ and in years gone by may never have got the help he required and could easily have died on the streets. But Encompass have adopted a new scheme called Housing First which started in the USA in the s and has since spread to Europe. The idea behind the approach is to give entrenched rough sleepers like Paul some control over where they live and how rather then assigning them places to live under strict rules and regulations. The British Government has recently invested poundm in Housing First pilot projects across the country. While Encompass have not received any of that money they have copied the approach and slowly persuaded Paul to live in his own flat after years on the streets. According to his Encompass support worker like Becky Fausset, , who has been working with rough sleepers for over  years, Paul’s new flat could very well be the dference between le and death. She said: “These are people that another winter and they could be dead and that is not being dramatic, so being able to get them into accommodation is very rewarding. “Housing First is dficult but incredibly positive, the dficulty is finding the properties, but so far it seems to be working. “People come to pretty places like Barnstaple and North Devon and don’t realise what is really going on and how many people are really struggling.” Paul finally moved in this week but when The Mirror visited the flat with him on Monday for the first time he was overwhelmed.  He said: “I can’t believe it, I feel like a real person again, someone that’s worth something, this is everything and I’m not going to let it go.” According to the latest research from the respected IPPR think-tank there was  per cent rise in rough sleeping in rural areas from  in  to  in . Butyou speak to people working on the front line of this problem they will tell you privately the true figures are likely to be much higher because the issue is so dficult to record. The Daily Mirror spent two days there with the dedicated staff of one homeless charity this week in a bid to highlight this worrying trend. We were hosted by the indomitable Claire Fisher, the CEO of Encompass.  Fighting her own personal battle against cancer Claire thinks nothing of manning the front lines each day and can be seen walking the streets and dishing out food to rough sleepers with her fellow colleagues. She explained how people could not believe areas like North Devon even had a homeless problem associating it with sunny holidays and second homes.  She said: “Believe it or not this is considered a deprived area round here which is really dficult to comprehend when you think of the beaches and the summer holidays but people are missing the reality of what le is like for people who live here year round. “We have a perfect storm here of a lack of industry, low paying jobs, zero hour contracts and a very low stock of social housing meaning people cannot afford to buy. “House prices are four times the average wage down here so they are reliant on the private rented sector and that is not always reliable.” She also pointed out how some rough sleepers actively choose to live in the countryside leaving them invisible to outside support. She said: “We do have people that choose to rough sleep in rural areas, purely because it is quieter, the risks are lower and they are not as open to abuse. Some of them can be very self sufficient. “I think a lot of the resources are focused on cities because it so visual there butyou come down here on holiday you don’t see it as much but actually we really have high numbers here and then others we are not aware of – we rely heavily on people like the Forestry Commission and farmers for tips about where people have set-up shop. “People need to realise that rural homelessness is happening, you may not see it, but it is all around you.”

title: brexit corbyn offers help theresa
story: NewsBrexit: Corbyn offers to help Theresa May PASS a deal - whats changed and why MPs are furiousJeremy Corbyn has written a bombshell letter to Theresa May offering a way to make Brexit happen. Heres the letter in full, whats changed - and why some MPs are angryShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsJeremy Corbyn has dropped a political hand grenade into the Brexit debate "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJeremy Corbyn has dropped a political hand grenade into the Brexit debate that could change the course of history. In a bombshell letter  days before Brexit, the Labour leader has shted his red lines and offered Theresa May a clear way to leave the EU -she backs a full customs union. It meansshe accepts his demands, Mrs May can get a House of Commons majority for Brexit. But firstly, thats a huge  that could split the Tories. Secondly, it throws a huge spanner in the works hours before the Prime Minister meets EU chiefs in Brussels today. And thirdly, its enraged some Labour MPs who want Jeremy Corbyn to stop helping the government push through Brexit - and back a second EU referendum instead. All that means its a long shot, and probably wont happen. But its still an important intervention in Brexit. So what is new today, how has Labour changed its position, and why are Remainer MPs angry  Heres our guide - and the letter in full.  Labours leader has written a letter to Theresa May, saying he WILL back her on a Brexit dealit meets five demands:A permanent, UK-wide customs union with the EU Close alignment with the EU single market Dynamic alignment on rights and protections, so UK standards keep pace with new ones in the EU Clear commitments on participation in EU agencies Unambiguous agreements on future securityMr Corbyn has already held talks with the Prime Minister and more are expected to follow. He promises to discuss his proposal with her in a constructive way to secure a sensible agreement. He says compromise is now needed to please both the EU and the House of Commons, which voted down the -page Brexit deal by a record majority last month.  Labour already backed a customs union. But this change in tactics is vital. Firstly, the letter means Labour has officially ditched its six tests a Brexit deal would have to meet before being backed. The tests were unveiled in March . They were based partly on Tory promises about Brexit, but included ambitions that were obviously impossible - such as securing the exact same benefits the UK currently has. They were derided as bollocks by Shadow Trade Secretary Barry Gardiner. Today the very same Mr Gardiner told the BBC: Its not about tests now. What we are doing is saying we believe that these are the options that are available that would actually secure a majority in the House of Commons. Secondly, it means Labour is putting calls for a second EU referendum firmly on the back burner - despite huge pressure within the party. Labour pledged to keep a second EU referendum as an option on the table thanks to a motion at the party conference last year. Remainers say Labour should campaigning for that public vote NOW, having failed to force a general election. But Jeremy Corbyn is against it. Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer was forced to intervene after a backlash, insisting the Labour leaders letter did not take the prospect of a public vote off the table. Thirdly, there is no mention in the letter of delaying Brexit. Labour has said extending the March  date may be inevitable. But this shows the party is still striving to help get a soft Brexit through as soon as it can. Why are some Labour MPs furious   Labour Remain-backers have voiced their fury at Jeremy Corbyn for - in their words - enabling Brexit. They want him to back a second EU referendum instead. And the words of Shadow Trade Secretary Barry Gardiner, who quoted Theresa May herself, wont help. He said: Jeremy is trying to set out what we believe is needed to make a success of Brexit. Labour MP Chuka Umunna blasted: This is not opposition, it is the facilitation of a deal which will make this country poorer. Labour MP Owen Smith said he was considering quitting the Labour Party.   Fellow Remainer MP Chris Leslie said: “Seriously  Offering to help Tory Govt enable Brexit  It’s not just Labour’s conference policy in the bin. When the jobs go  revenues for services dry up as a result, Labour’s leadership will have ZERO right to complain: they share responsibility.” Labour MP Tonia Antoniazzi wrote sarcastically: Nice to be briefed about this @UKLabour @WelshLabour. If at ANY point you would like to consult MPs and also take the Labour Party conference motion into consideration... Just let me know... Cheers...  For the first time, it means Theresa May doesnt need to change the backstop - or appease Tory Brexiteers - to get her deal through. The backstop is an insurance clause that would trap the UK under EU customs rules from , in exchange for keeping the Irish border open. The Prime Minister is meeting EU chiefs in Brussels today to try and tweak the clause. Shes done that because Tory Brexiteers said otherwise, theres no way they would pass the Brexit deal. Yet EU chiefs say they wont change the backstop, leaving talks deadlocked. Now Labour claims it has a way out by offering that permanent customs union - arranged, crucially, through the future framework and not the -page exit deal that contains the backstop. If she backs it, Labour claims, Theresa May wont need Tory Brexiteer help to get a Commons majority. Barry Gardiner said: What were saying is actually you can do this another way. What you can do is say lets look at the future political framework, andthe future political framework were agreed now between the EU and ourselves to be a customs union, then actually theres no problem at that point when you get to the end of the transition period, because youre already in a customs union and therefore you dont need the backstop.  Theresa May has made clear she wants to be able to strike trade deals around the world. If the UK is in a full customs union with the EU, she cant do that. And Labour proposed a customs union before - only to be defeated in the House of Commons. Evenshe did fold and accept a customs union, the row over it could split Theresa Mays party for good. Tory Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg once warned of a revolt the size of that over the Victorian-era Corn Laws. There is one important upshot though. If Theresa May refuses Jeremy Corbyns offer, he can reasonably pin the blame on herit leads to a No Deal Brexit.  A No spokeswoman said: The letter has been received and we will reply in due course. Many of our positions on many of the issues in the letter are well known. The PMs focus is on securing changes to the backstop. Thats what she is focused on today. But a No spokeswoman repeatedly declined to say Theresa May will put any specic proposals to EU leaders today to solve the deadlock. She said: She will be discussing the ongoing urgent work we have been undertaking since the vote to secure the changes that mean we can secure parliamentary support. She added: You know our position on the customs union and that has not changed. No new meetings with Corbyn were confirmed as of am but Mrs Mays door remains open. What happens next   Theresa May is meeting EU chiefs including Donald Tusk and Jean-Claude Juncker in Brussels today. Theyre likely to brush her off, a day after saying Tory Brexiteers who had no plan have a special place in hell. Then shes travelling to Dublin on Friday night for dinner with Irish premier Leo Varadkar. Hes likely to brush her off too. But in between and afterwards, theres a window for talks with Jeremy Corbyn and his top team about the offer. David Lidington, her de facto deputy, said there would be a channel open to Labour. Shes unlikely to have a new deal ready by next week, meaning MPs will get a vote directing the way forward on February . That could bind her hands, delay Brexit, or just leave us in more deadlock as time ticks down to March .  Dear Prime Minister, Thank you for taking the time to meet last week to discuss the Brexit negotiation and our alternative approaches to finding a deal that can command support in Parliament and be negotiated with the EU. There is, as was demonstrated last week, a clear majority in Parliament that no deal must now be taken off the table and that there can be noto a hard border in Northern Ireland in any circumstance. We recognise that your priority is now to seek legally binding changes to the backstop arrangements contained within the Withdrawal Agreement, as we discussed when we met. However, without changes to your negotiating red lines, we do not believe that simply seeking modications to the existing backstop terms is a credible or sufficient response either to the scale of your defeat last month in Parliament, or the need for a deal with the EU that can bring the country together and protect jobs. As you have said many times before, the EU has been clear that any withdrawal agreement would need to include a backstop to guarantee noto a hard border on the island of Ireland. Labour has long argued that the Government should change its negotiating red lines and seek signicant changes to the Political Declaration to provide clarity on our future relationship and deliver a closer economic relationship with the EU. That would also ensure that any backstop would be far less likely to be invoked. The changes we would need to see include: * A permanent and comprehensive UK-wide customs union. This would include alignment with the union customs code, a common external tarf and an agreement on commercial policy that includes a UK say on future EU trade deals. We believe that a customs union is necessary to deliver the frictionless trade that our businesses, workers and consumers need, and is the only viable way to ensure there is no hard border on the island of Ireland. As you are aware, a customs union is supported by most businesses and trade unions. * Close alignment with the Single Market. This should be underpinned by shared institutions and obligations, with clear arrangements for dispute resolution. * Dynamic alignment on rights and protections so that UK standards keep pace with evolving standards across Europe as a minimum, allowing the UK to lead the way. * Clear commitments on participation in EU agencies and funding programmes, including in areas such as the environment, education, and industrial regulation. * Unambiguous agreements on the detail of future security arrangements, including access to the European Arrest Warrant and vital shared databases. We believe these negotiating objectives need to be enshrined in law before the UK leaves the EU to provide certainty for businesses and a clear framework for our future relationship. We recognise that any negotiation with the EU will require flexibility and compromise. Our first priority must be a deal that is best for jobs, living standards, our communities, in the context of increased and more equitable investment across all regions and nations of the UK. That approach should guide how alignment with EU regulations is to be maintained in future, as well discussions on dispute resolution, the role of the ECJ, and competition and migration rules. EU leaders have been clear that such changes to the Political Declaration and a closer relationship are possiblesuch a request is made by the UK government andthe current red lines change. We believe that a close economic relationship along these lines would make it far less likely that any backstop arrangements would ever be needed. The Government’s failure to secure a deal that can command the support of Parliament means time has run out for the necessary preparation and for legislation to be finalised. Following last week’s rejection by the House of Commons of ‘no deal’, all necessary steps must be taken to avoid such an outcome. My colleagues and I look forward to discussing these proposals with you further, in the constructive manner in which they are intended, with the aim of securing a sensible agreement that can win the support of parliament and bring the country together. Yours sincerely, Jeremy Corbyn MP Leader of the Opposition

title: brexit glaring theresa kicks vote
story: NewsBrexit: Glaring Theresa May kicks vote back as far as MARCH after robust Brussels talksIt could be weeks before glaring Theresa May goes to Brussels again after EU chief Jean-Claude Juncker rebuffed her bid to reopen talksShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video theresa-may-refuses-to-smile-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailStony-faced Theresa May kicked MPs Brexit vote back as far as MARCH today after struggling through robust talks with Brussels. EU chief Jean-Claude Juncker rebuffed her bid to reopen talks on the -page Brexit deal - including a controversial backstop. So the pair have now arranged further talks - but only before the end of February. And questioned today, a No spokeswoman refused to rule out putting a revised deal to MPs in March - which would be just weeks before the UK leaves the EU on March .   Instead the No spokeswoman said: Were working to bring it back as soon as possible. Mrs May, whose convoy was ambushed by anti-Brexit protester, pointedly did not raise a smile as she arrived and shook hands with Mr Juncker at EU headquarters.  She also held talks with EU Parliament chiefs Guy Verhofstadt and Antonio Tajani, and EU Council President Donald Tusk - who said yesterday there was a special place in hell for Tory Brexiteers. She confronted Tusk over his hell remark, telling reporters it caused widespread dismay.But despite just  days being left to Brexit, it is believed Mrs May put forward no specic solutions today to break the deadlock. She told Mr Juncker she will continue to seek legally binding changes to the -page Brexit deal. Yet Mr Juncker made clear that the EU will not reopen talks on the deal.  Mrs May has promised MPs a general vote next Thursday  February which will let them direct the way forward. But this is not the same as a meaningful vote to pass or defeat her Brexit plan, with legal effect. Now, with talks on deadlock, there are fears that meaningful vote will only be held weeks before the UK leaves the EU.   One government source told the Mirror they feared the clock ticking down as late as March  before a deal is struck. And a joint statement issued by Mrs May and Mr Juncker today did not commit to a firm timeframe. The discussion was robust but constructive, the statement said. Despite the challenges, the two leaders agreed that their teams should hold talks as to whether a way through can be found that would gain the broadest possible support in the UK Parliament and respect the guidelines agreed by the European Council.  The Prime Minister and the President will meet again before the end of February to take stock of these discussions. BrexitSecretary Stephen Barclay and EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier will also meet next Monday. The statement confirmed Mrs May set out MPs demands for a legally binding change to the backstop - an insurance clause that would keep the UK trapped under EU customs rules. Yet Mr Juncker underlined that the EU will not reopen the Withdrawal Agreement, which contains the backstop. Instead he is only willing to negotiate the separate political declaration, which spells out future trade. In a glimmer of hope, EU Parliament Brexit co-ordinator Guy Verhofstadt said the political declaration could be upgraded to make it more binding.  He told reporters: Our proposal is to try to solve the problem in the political declaration. We are open as Parliament from Day One to upgrade this political declaration to make this political declaration more binding, more precise. Also on the issue of the backstop, explaining and saying very clearly that this is an insurance, not more than that. Mr Verhofstadt added that Mrs May assured him there is no question to remove a backstop. Meanwhile Jeremy Corbyn has offered Theresa May a way out of the mess.  Labours leader vowed to back her deal -she guarantees a full customs union with the EU. But Mrs May has already said she does not want a customs union, meaning the offer is unlikely to be taken up. And the big offer has enraged some Labour MPs who want Mr Corbyn to back a second referendum instead. Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer was forced to intervene after a backlash, insisting the Labour leaders letter did not take the prospect of a public vote off the table.

title: no deal brexit mobile phone
story: NewsNo Deal Brexit: Mobile phone roaming charges face immediate rise after March Tory ministers have been accused of "sneaking out" the end of free EU roaming laws in an obscure law just  days before BrexitShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsGuaranteed EU free roaming launched in  - but you can kiss it goodbye in no deal"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMobile roaming charges face an immediate hikethere is a No Deal Brexit, the government has confirmed. Tory ministers are revoking the EU law which guarantees UK citizens pay the same for using their phone on the Continent as they do at home. That will leave mobile phone firms free to hike costs whenever they like after the UK leaves. Guaranteed free roaming launched across the EU just  months ago - and meant big savings. But that guarantee will be scrappedthere is no deal, thanks to an obscure law laid before Parliament this week.   The current system caps the costs charged between EU and UK phone operators, letting them pass on the savings to customers. But the Mobile RoamingRegulations admit these caps will have no legal forcethere is no Brexit deal. That means phone giants could see their wholesale costs spiral, making roaming packages unaffordable and forcing them to push up costs, the government warns. Under the new rules, customers will still be prompted once theyve spent pound to prevent massive accidental bills. Travellers will also be prompted when theyve hit % and % of their data allowance. But it will spell the end of guaranteed free roaming across the EU, notes on the new law admit.  Alex Neill of consumer group Which  told HuffPost UK: “Anyto sky-high charges for using mobile phones abroad would be a bitter blow for millions of consumers. “The government should seek to avoid these charges by securing a deal with the EU. Butthat is not the outcome, companies must be absolutely clear about any extra charges their customers could be facing. Back when warnings first emerged about an end to roaming, the government insisted firms would not hike charges because of market competition. But MoneySavingExpert revealed last week that just two out of  major UK phone firms have guaranteed to keep free roaming in a No Deal Brexit . Most said they had no plans to raise charges - but stopped short of giving a cast-iron guarantee.  Consumer groups lobbied the government to keep roaming free by law. But after careful consideration the government did not agree, because it would pass all the costs on to phone firms. That, in turn, could have pushed up the cost of mobile phone tarfs overall to compensate, an explanatory note to the new law says. Shadow Brexit minister Jenny Chapman said: “These proposals prove that it will be holidaymakers and businesses that are forced to pay the price for this government’s incompetence. “It’s unacceptable that these plans have been snuck out. Ministers need to start being straight with the British public about the consequences of no deal and take it off the table once and for all.  The anti-Brexit group Best For Britain branded the fiasco the Last Days of Roam and claimed business travellers could be forced to pay pound more per month. Lib Dem MP Layla Moran said: The cost of a hard Brexit on British travellers is becoming abundantly clear. Millions of people are facing higher costs to make calls and texts abroad because of the Prime Ministers botched Brexit plans. A Department for Culture, Media and Sport spokesperson said: “In the event we leave the EU without a deal, the continuation of surcharge-free mobile roaming for UK citizens travelling in the EU would be a commercial decision for the operators.”

title: beautiful mum infectious laugh found
story: NewsBeautul mum with an infectious laugh found dead at home aged just Ellie Majors dad said his daughter did not mean to take her own le after she was found with a lethal cocktail of drugs in her systemShareByTom Kershaw:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsEllie was found dead at home "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe heartbroken family of a beautul mum with an infectious laugh have paid tribute after she was found dead at her home.Ellie Major, , died with a lethal cocktail of prescription drugs in her system.Ms Majors dad said she did not mean to take her own le at her home in Hessle, Hull Live reports.Her family described her as a brilliant mum to her son, aged three. Paying tribute, Ms Majors sister, Emily Major, , said: You can see from the pictures how beautul and stunning my sister was. She was a loving and caring parent and a brilliant mother to her three-year-old son. She had a really distinctive and infectious laugh. At the inquest, coroner Professor Paul Marks said the evidence showed Ms Majors death was an accident.   Ms Majors father, Mark David Major, said she had been looking forward to spending time on two booked holidays. He said: I think it was just an accident. She was just wanting to get her high. Ellie did not mean to take her own le and under estimated the strength of her tablets.The mum-of-one had been diagnosed with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, a type of arthritis effecting her joints, when she was aged  and was prescribed painkillers to deal with the pain.An inquest into her death atHull Coroners Courtheard Ms Major had attempted to end her own le by overdosing on drugs in March , which resulted in her losing custody over her son. But it had taken six months for her to be assessed by mental health experts because she was not a high risk - a decision which her family said had contributed to her poor mental health.   Ms Majors social worker told the hearing that the young mum had been “at the bottom of her list” because she was at a low medium risk. She told the hearing through tears: When I found out about Ellie’s death I was following up an appointment with her. I never accepted it, and that is what has thrown me so much. When I spoke with Ellie, she reassured me that her previous attempt to take her own le was impulsive and she was very remourseful. But Ms Majors heartbroken mother Marie Mitchell, , said it was beyond her she had been deemed a low risk. She said: How they can say there is not an urgent risk for a mum who tried to take her own le is beyond me - and her first assessment only happened six months later. Service manager at the Humber NHS Trust Jo Kent had put together a report and said no lessons had been learnt since Ellie’s tragic death.  Workers at the mental health teams said that Ellie had not attended planned meetings. The family also demanded answers over why Ellie was still being given eight dferent types of medication, despite her using the drugs to take her own le previously. Mr Major said he grew concerned about his daughter when he did not receive a WhatsApp message from her. She was found dead in her home in Hessle on August , . Police Officer John Norcross found “boxes and bags of prescription drugs” across the property. PC Norcross told the hearing: There was no evidence of third party involvement or anything suspicious.  Dr Ian Richmond, consultant histopathologist, said that the medical cause of death was multiple drug toxicity. Concluding the inquest as an open conclusion, coroner Professor Paul Marks said the evidence showed Ms Majors death was an accident. He said: The evidence heard today could make me believe up to the civil standard of proof, that I am persuaded by her fathers communication, this is probably an accident. The family said they would be looking to lodge a complaint with the NHS and take things further. Her heartbroken mother Marie said: It is better than what we were expecting, but we still have a lot of unanswered questions which we couldnt ask because the GP didnt have Ellies notes in front of him. If you need help, Samaritans operate a free   phone service on  .

story: NewsCouple’s £, holiday ruined by ft seaweed mountains on luxury beachLaurel Cormack and David Crook, from Essex, have blasted TUI after claiming their Corfu stay was marred by seaweed mountainsShareCommentsByHelen Le Caplain:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news weird-news video familys--holiday-ruined-seaweed-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA furious couple have said their pound, dream holiday was ruined - by stinking ft seaweed mountains which meant they couldnt use the beach. Sun lovers Laurel Cormack and David Crook say the luxury five-star resort in Corfu looked like a swamp. They had been looking forward to spending two weeks at TUIs Mayor Verde Grand Resort in Agios Gordios, which has a well-publicised private beach. However when the couple got there they found the usually golden sands littered with towering ft-wide smelly seaweed mounds buzzing with flies. David claims they were only able to spend half a day on the hotel beach and had to abandon their sunbeds due to the seaweed-choked waters and head to the crowded hotel pool.   The recruitment consultant blasted TUIs cavalier attitude to their complaints and for failing to inform guests of the natural phenomenon in advance so they could make alternative plans. TUI said they were sorry to hear of their disappointment and would be in contact with them again. David, from Southend-on-Sea, Essex, said: Were very much beach people and always book hotels with their own piece of beach with them. If were relaxing we prefer to sit on the beach rather than by the pool as it always gets crowded. The black seaweed was in very long strips andyou put your foot in it it would stick to your legs. In the water it was ft deep.   The seaweed was smelly and had a lot of flies around it, the water wasnt clear either. The holiday wasnt as good as it could have been as the one facility we paid for [the beach], the whole reason we picked that hotel, we werent able to take advantage of. When we booked the holiday online I was expecting the golden sands I saw in the brochure, not mounds of stinking seaweed. The -year-old said both he and his customer service assistant we Laurel, , were taunted by glossy promotional videos displayed in the hotel showcasing the resorts unspoiled beaches.  David said: The really irritating thing was in the main reception they had a big -inch TV with a continuous looped video. It kept showing all the bits of the hotel that wed booked the holiday for and werent able to use because they were seaweeded out. They were even playing in the lts and showing the same thing - we couldnt get away from them. Grandad-of-one David said that diggers were out at am scooping up the seaweed from the sand and dumping it in mounds on the hotel area of the beach instead of taking it away. David said: When we complained about it the TUI rep shrugged her shoulders and said theres nothing we can do, the hotel and local authority is doing all they can.  The diggers were there a couple of hours from am on a few mornings trying to clear the beach but as fast as they moved it the seaweed ed. They werent removing it though just piling it up, it was an eyesore. Apparently a couple of weeks before we were there there was a dredger that took away about  tonnes of seaweed. We werent there for that but you dont order a dredger and get diggers on the beachits not a problem. We could have used the less affected public beach further along but that would have entailed paying for sunbeds, parasols and snacks which defeats the object of going all inclusive. Our argument has always been never about assigning blame or responsibility for the seaweed. Its a natural phenomena, its not the hotel or TUIs fault and I never said it was.  What I was really incensed about was the fact that all theyre doing is hiding behind it being a natural phenomena. It first started at the end of March and we went in June - theyd known about this for three months. Do they not monitor their resorts for this type of event  Do they not noty customers  If wed had an informed choice we wouldnt have cancelled our holiday, but we would have just gone to a dferent resort not affected by it. I dont want a load of money back, I just want them to hold their hands up and admit its something they should have made people aware of.  I wouldnt want other people to go through the experience, its just wrong. David complained to TUI in writing and said he was disappointed with their response - even receiving a missive thoughtlessly sent out. David said: I had an email from one TUI rep again explaining it was a natural phenomenon and that she was sorry about the incontinence this has caused. My first thought was that the email hadnt been put through spell check or checked for any autocorrects it was just speedily bashed out with little or no thought. Ive also tried speaking to them on the phone and on one glorious occasion was on hold for  minutes listening to a continuous loop of the same song - by the end of it I was losing the will to live. Dad-of-two David said the experience had put him off booking a TUI holiday in the future. David said: The cavalier attitude TUI took has meant that we will never use them again and nor would we recommend them. The amount we paid might not be a lot of money to a lot of people, but its a big chunk of money for us. Were not wealthy people were just normal working people - its our two weeks of rest and relaxation. TUIs whole attitude really disappointed me, its just left a really bad taste in the mouth. I never said it was their fault, all I was saying was do you not monitor your resorts for this kind of occurrences to let people know so they can make an informed choice about whether they want to proceed with it or not  A TUI spokesman said: Were sorry to hear of the Cormack partys disappointment and we will be in contact the customers directly once again to discuss in further detail.

title: defiant couple saves 15000 refusing
story: NewsDefiant couple save £, by refusing to turn on central heating for ten yearsJoanne and Jim Bell have braved British winters - and now say other peoples homes are too warmShareCommentsByIan Williams:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThey say they just wear plenty of layers and use hot water bottles to keep warm "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA defiant couple has saved themselves pound, by refusing to use their central heating for the last ten years.Joanne and Jim Bell of Yelland, Devon, have not been deterred by the freezing British winters.They say they have no intention of quitting and claim theyve adapted so well neither of them has been ill in that time. And they have saved thousands of pounds. They recently spent pound, attending live concerts by Neil Young and Bob Dylan with the money they saved on heating bills. Wildle lover Mrs Bell said the move was originally made in protest at the proleration of wind farms. But now their bodies had adapted so well it had become normal.   It feels uncomfortable when Im in other peoples houses now, she said. Its too warm for me. Our heating bills used to be about pound a year so weve saved thousands over ten years. When it gets very cold we just wear plenty of layers and use hot water bottles. I dont notice the cold any more.   She added: Weve got two dogs and do plenty of walking which keeps you warm. It cant be that bad because neither of us has been ill in that time. Im a wildle lover and when I saw so many birds being killed by the blades of the wind turbines popping up everywhere I just felt I wanted to do something. Now I dont know any dferent - Im so used to it. Mrs Bell,  added: Im not recommending it for everyone. If you have sick or elderly relatives you simply couldnt do it oryou have young children it wouldnt be possible.

title: emiliano salas dog waiting him
story: NewsEmiliano Salas dog waiting for him broke hearts - heres other pooches devotion to dead ownersThe Premier League stars dog, Nala, has been pictured waiting patiently for her owner to ShareCommentsByLouise Elliott:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsSalas dog, Nala, waits patiently for hisfollowing the plane crash"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The tragic image of Emiliano Sala s dog waiting for him tohas broken hearts around the world. Sala went missing aboard a piper malibu aircraft over the English Channel on January  shortly after signing for Cardf in a club-record, poundmillion deal.Both the wreckage and a body have since been discovered but it has not yet been identied.Salas devastated sister, Romina, posted a b[icture of his beloved dog , Nala, on Facebook .It shows the pooch, looking out of the window and staring into the distance - waiting for his master to .   Romina captioned the image: Nala is waiting for you, too. Sala had a very close relationship with his dog, with Nala reportedly one of the reasons the star ed to France. It is understood the Argentinian had taken Nala to kennels and was in the process of moving her to Wales to live with him. She loved to chase animals and to go on long walks with the Premier Legue star. If Salas familys worst fears are confirmed, the footballers sister has vowed to look after Nala.   But devoted Labrador Nala is not the only dog to show heartbreaking devotion to her owner after theyve passed away. Many dogs have waited patiently, forever, for their masters to . Their devotion, loyalty and service dont end long after their owners have gone. Greyfriars Bobby is arguably the most famous of these devoted dogs.  The terrier belonged to John Gray, who worked in for Edinburgh City Police as a night watchman. Bobby was so devastated he spent the next  years sitting on Grays grave until he too died in . There is now a statue of Bobby on the corner of Edinburghs Candlemakers Row and George IV bridge. Police officer and his loyal pal  Constable David Ross, a Canadian mounted police officer, was killed in the line of duty in . His devoted service dog and pooch partner, Danny, was heartbroken that his master was gone. Danny could be heard whimpering throughout Con Rosss funeral and even snfed the stetson of his officer pal. Presidential grief  President George Bushs labrador service dog was heartbroken at his death. Sully was pictured resting beside his coffin in a moving tribute to his former master. The dog even travelled with President Bushs casket when it was transported on Air Force One from Texas to Washington. Even floods wont stop this dog  After this dogs owner was killed in the floods in Brazil, the pooch refused to leave his graveside. Leao coldnt bare leaving Cristina Maria Cesario Sanatnas side, even in death. Film star pooch  Hidesaburo Ueno was killed in an accident at work in . For nine years his loyal dog Hachiko, an Akita, waited for his master toat Tokyo train station. His devotion to his human best friends was turned into a film by Richard Gere. Guest of honour  Not even death could break the powerful bond between loyal dog Hawkeye and his handler, navy SEAL Jon Tumilson. The cherished black labrador led Tumilsons family into the funeral in Iowa in . Petty Officer Tumilson was one of  SEALS killed when their Chinook helicopter was shot down by Afghan insurgents. Determined dog  Border collie Spot trekked four miles, crossing a main road, canal and rail line, to find the grave of owner Denis Goodier in Macclesfield, Cheshire. Grave guard  Pop star George Michaels dog Abby, who used to lie at his shrine, died last year at . Fans came from all over the world to meet Abby on her walks in Highgate, north London, after his Christmas Day death in . Grief-stricken terrier  Robbie the terrier sat at the side of his dead owner without moving for three days, in temperatures in the s, in the US city of Milwaukee. Royal rover  After the death of King Edward VII on May , , his dog Caesar refused to eat and spent time whining outside the Kings bedroom.At the funeral, Caesar walked with a Highlander behind the carriage carrying the Kings coffin.The dog was placed before the heads of state in the procession.

story: NewsHaunting letter of Brit, , shared moments before he ended le in wes arms at DignitasGeoff Whaley, , said his final weeks were "blighted" by police who questioned his we Ann, , about her involvement and in a final letter published as he ended his le, he urged MPs to change the law on assisted suicideShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror tv tv-news video geoff-whaley-ending-le-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAt am this morning Geoff Whaley died in his wes arms at a Dignatis clinic after sipping a cup of water laced with lethal drugs. The moment had been a long time coming for Mr Whaley who travelled from his home in Chalfont St Peter in Buckinghamshire to the facility in Switzerland with we Ann, adopted children Alix and Dominic, and some close friends. But before the -year-old took his last breath surrounded by his loved ones, there was one final thing he needed to do - publish a haunting letter he hoped would be his legacy.He titled it: By the time you read this, I will be dead and addressed it to all Members of Parliament urging them to change the law surrounding assisted suicide .  No family should ever have to endure the torment we have undergone in recent weeks, the retired accountant wrote. But it will be easier to bear knowing that by sharing it we can contribute to future change. Mr Whaley, a grandfather-of-four, was diagnosed with Motor Neurone Disease, an incurable, terminal illness, in . As the years passed he lost the use of his limbs. His ability to speak, swallow and breath also began to rapidly deteriorate. However, he knew the worst was still to come which is why he chose to die in Switzerland rather than face immense suffering in the end stages of the devastating condition.He admitted to the BBC : This is one of the illnesses you wouldnt wish on your worst enemy.  But not only was Mr Whaley crippled by the disease in his final weeks, he says he suffered immense anguish at the hands of police and social services who were tipped off about Mr Whaleys plans. Mrs Whaley, , found herself being interviewed under caution by Thames Valley Police. And Mr Whaley said the added stress of police involvement had destroyed everything we had done to prepare ourselves. He wrote: I was saying my final goodbyes and preparing myself for the end, the final, biggest bomb dropped and I could no longer keep it together.   This bomb was in fact an anonymous phone call to social services who informed the police of my plans to go to Switzerland. Within hours Ann and I were facing a criminal investigation. The thought that I might not make it to Switzerland, or that,I did, Ann might be facing  years in jail for helping me, was almost too much to bear. Mrs Whaley, , who supported her husbands decision, told the BBC it was the first time in their  years of marriage that she had ever seen her husband cry. He said everything that Ive worked for to protect you has all been blown apart by this anonymous phone call, she said.   I wasnt frightened because I didnt feel like Id done anything wrong. I wasnt ashamed. I was cross. There was a policewoman and a detective sergeant and they were clearly not expecting to find a non-abusive situation because they were very embarrassed about the whole thing. Helping someone commit suicide is punishable by up to  years in prison. Mrs Whaley booked the flights to Switzerland and a hotel because her husband could no longer use his hands. It was so ridiculous to put us through this when he is in the final few days of le, she said. Police have since dropped the case, but the couple want to see the law changed to allow assisted dying in some circumstances.  They believe the law can be written to ensure vulnerable people are still protected from abuse. Mrs Whaley admitted: I just want him to be here, but I know what he has chosen to do is the right thing for him.I wouldnt put an animal through what he would go throughhe went to the end. At least three Britons have faced a police investigation after ing from a loved ones assisted death at a Dignitas clinic, the Times reported, although no-one has been prosecuted. When askedhe is concerned about the consequences his we could face, Mr Whaley, who spent his last night having dinner with his family at a hotel in Zurich, replied: Ann can handle anything. The one thing that has worried me all along is leaving Ann because Ive spent all my le protecting her. Now shell be without me, but I know shell get through it. Mr Whaleys letter to MPs in full: Dear Members of Parliament, By the time you read this, I will be dead. On Thursday th February , I will have taken medication that will end my le, surrounded by my we, Ann, my children, Alix and Dominic, and a couple of my dearest friends at the Dignitas facility in Switzerland. With their love and support I have been able to fulfil my final wish: to be in control of my end, rather than endure the immense suffering motor neurone disease had in store for me. I want to impress upon you the anguish me and my family have experienced, not because of this awful illness , but because of the law against assisted dying in this country. The blanket ban on assisted dying has not only forced me to spend thousands of pounds and endure months of logistical hurdles in order to secure a peaceful and dignied death overseas, but it has meant that my final weeks of le have been blighted by visits from social services and police. Since my diagnosis of MND, an incurable, terminal illness, in , I felt as though bombs have been dropping on me. I gradually lost the use of all four limbs. My ability to speak, swallow and breathe began rapidly deteriorating. I knew my death was inevitable and unavoidable, but I remained strong for my family. I am  years old and have lived a full le. I did not fear death, but I did fear the journey. I simply wanted to cut this suffering short by a few months. When I eventually got the ‘green light’ from Dignitas, a weight lted I was able to get on with living without the constant mental anguish over my death. But then, as I was saying my final goodbyes and preparing myself for the end, the final, biggest bomb dropped and I could no longer keep it together. This bomb was in fact an anonymous phone call to social services who informed the police of my plans to go to Switzerland. Within hours Ann and I were facing a criminal investigation. The thought that I might not make it to Switzerland, or that,I did, Ann might be facing  years in jail for helping me, was almost too much to bear. In  years of marriage, Ann had not seen me cry. The day we were contacted by the police, I sobbed. The law in this country robbed me of control over my death. It forced me to seek solace in Switzerland. Then it sought to punish those attempting to help me get there. The hypocrisy and cruelty of this is astounding. Though it is perfectly legal for me make arrangements and travel to Dignitas by myself, the minute anyone  ‘assists’ me in any way – which is essential, due to my condition – they are liable for prosecution. I had the chance, just over a week before my death, to speak to some MPs and Peers about my experience and my adamant wish that the law should be changed. The overwhelming reaction in the room was one of agreement however, I am aware that despite huge public support for an assisted dying law, most members of parliament currently oppose it. I spoke to one MP who had voted against the last assisted dying Bill in . The law being proposed was limited to terminally ill, mentally competent adults in their final months, with strict inbuilt safeguards to protect the vulnerable and anyone  who has not made a clear decision of their own volition. When I pressed her on why she felt people like me should be denied a say over our own death and be forced to suffer, she was unable to articulate an answer. I want MPs to know that change is urgently needed and that it is achievable – over  million people in several American and Australian states and across Canada are covered by assisted dying laws which allow choice to dying people and protection to others. No family should ever have to endure the torment we have undergone in recent weeks, but it will be easier to bear knowing that by sharing it we can contribute to future change. I sincerely hope that you will truly listen to our story and see the suffering you are inflicting by upholding the status quo. Yours sincerely, Geoffrey Whaley

story: NewsMum thought shed met love of her le on blind date - but he was WRONG manJacky Rom now wants to track down the mystery man, in Chelmsford, Essex, as he was much nicer than her actual Plenty of Fish dateShareCommentsByPaige Ingram:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsJacky Rom is desperate to track down the man she met by accident in an Essex pub "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who went on a blind date thought shed found the love of her le - only to discover shed sat down with the wrong man. story: NewsHomeless Britain: The hard-working builder who ended up on streets after breaking his back - and we evicted on birthday#MirrorOnTheStreet: Mirror reporters found Donna living on the street in Cardf - taking pride in her tent complete with air fresheners and keeping everything tidyShareCommentsByRachael Bletchly:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video mirroronthestreet-campaign-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailExhausted Steve finishes the hot drink a caring passer-by bought him then climbs inside his blue one-man tent. He winces with pain as he plumps his grubby duvet and lies down, zipping the flap shut behind him Because in , roofer Steve broke his back in three places falling off a building, and sleeping on a wet, cold street is agony. “After the fall I lost my job and my home,” he croaks through a sore throat . “I came home to the Rhondda then ended up here on the streets six weeks ago. “I went to a hostel one night but got pick-pocketed while I was sleeping and the place was full of druggies.The second time I had night terrors and a member of staff woke me up by slapping me, hard. So I feel safer here. “But it’s bloody miserable. I just want my own place again, to get back on my feet.” Steve is just one of dozens of tent dwellers living in the centre of Cardf who reveal the complexity of Britain’s rough-sleeping crisis.   There were some , homeless people in Wales last year – a rise of % in  months – with , in the capital. But the number of rough sleepers in Cardf doubled in three years, to around . Last month a Tory councillor was suspended, though later reinstated, for demanding their tents be “torn down” as they were harming local businesses. And since “tentgate” made headlines, even more people have appeared under canvas on the city’s streets.But Cardf has some of the best homeless services in the UK, with hundreds of places in council and charity-run hostels and outreach teams offering support. Every night there are least  surplus bed spaces. So why does anyone need to sleep in a tent or doorway   Rough sleepers say they feel safety on the streets and maintain their independence. Charities blame the lack of social housing, rent increases, welfare reforms and the Universal Credit debacle – along with an “explosion” in spice use and substance addiction in Cardf, and an increase in mental health issues.  Those they do help into accommodation cannot always maintain it, leading to what council outreach workers call “a revolving door of homelessness”. But tent dwellers like Steve dream of having a real front door again. So does Donna. She and her husband Paul, , have been living in a tent in the pedestrian shopping area for three weeks.  They were evicted on Donna’s th birthday, when their landlord suddenly sold up. Paul has recovered from a stroke and a heart attack and beaten bowel cancer, and both he and Donna have mental health issues. “We’ve been to a hostel, but never again,” she says. “It was filthy used needles in the shower, people openly taking drugs and robbing each other. It’s no good for you. “Sleeping in doorways is far too dangerous, so a tent is the best solution.  “It keeps you warm and dry and out of the way of the shop owners trying to make a living.” She invites me in to her immaculately kept tent. We sit on a brightly coloured patchwork blanket surrounded by all her belongings, lined up neatly or packed in bags. There is even an air freshener in the corner and a pint of milk keeping cool by the door. “I take pride in keeping it nice,” she says. “I sweep it all out every day. Everything’s got to be tidy.  “And we’re on a the waiting list for accommodation, so hopefully it won’t be long before we’re out of here. I just want to get back behind my own front door again.” But for now, like Steve and the other tent dwellers, a zipped-up a flap of canvas will have to do.
