Officers are now appealing for witnesses and anyone with information is asked to come forward.Inspector Kevin Sinclair from Dalkeith Police Station said: ldquoThis has been a frightening experience for the victim who was thankfully uninjured but understandably very shaken by the ordeal.ldquoThis sort of behaviour is completely unacceptable. I would ask anyone who witnessed the group of youths in this area last night, or the incident in the underpass, to come forward to help with our investigation.ldquoAnyone who may be able to identy those involved, or have any information to help us trace them, should call us as soon as possible.The first suspect is described as white, ft ins tall, about  years old, of medium build with blond hair that had curls at the front. He was wearing black tracksuit bottoms, trainers and a black hoodie.The second is described as a white male, of slim build, with dark brown hair and was wearing black jogging bottoms, a black scarf over his mouth and a black hoodiewith writing on the front, possibly lsquoNorth Face.rsquoThe third suspect is described as a white male, smaller and younger than the others involved, wearing grey jogging bottoms and a black hoodie.Anyone with information shouldcontact Police Scotland on , quoting incident number  of  January, or Crimestoppers anonymously on   .

title: cold-weather-makes-it-harder-for-us-to-get-out-of-bed-says-survey
story: Weneed an extra  minutes in bed each morning during winter before wefeel brave enough to face the cold, according to a new survey.Of those surveyed who are currently employed,  per cent thought they were more likely to be late for work in the winter months because they found it harder to get up in the morning.Andof that %,the average worker will be late for work seven times in the course of an average winter because they overslept.One in five have been so cosy they have pulled a sickie to have a duvet day instead.A spokesperson for Andrews Heat for Hire, which commissioned the study, said: ldquoDarker, colder mornings can make waking up in winter months more challenging than any other time of the year.ldquoAnd while an additional quarter of an hour snoozing each day doesnrsquot seem like a big sacrice, over the course of the winter we lose an entire day to those few extra minutes in bed.Regionally, Scots are the quickest to get up and face the day when the weather turns, spending  minutes extra in bed, while those living in Yorkshire are fondest of their covers, resisting the cold until theyrsquove had  extra minutes dozing.One in two Brits find it harder to get themselves out of bed in winter more than any other time of year, and a third think they are more likely to hit the snooze button when the mornings are dark and cold.And seven in  said a few more minutes with their duvet is too tempting when the weather outside looks chilly.To read the full results of the study, visitandrews-sykes blog.Three in five of those questioned make it tougher to leave their beds by taking actions to make their set-up as warm and comfortable as possible.Of these,  per cent will buy a thicker duvet when the weather begins to turn, and  per cent will put an extra blanket on the bed to keep the cold away.More than seven in  even have the foresight to set their heating to come on before they wake up so their home is warm when they wake, clicking on  minutes before they stir.One in five of those surveyed have been so attached to their bedspread they have been late for a meet-up with friends or loved ones - and will also cancel six gatherings entirely over a typical winter because its too cold.Nearly one in two Brits are unable to shake their hibernation instincts when the temperature plummets and spend more time in bed during the winter than any other time of year.Three in  find themselves going to bed earlier as the evenings draw in sooner, and one in eight set their morning alarms later than they usually would to grab a few extra minutes before feeling the chill.A spokesperson for Andrews Heat for Hire, who comissioned the survey, said: ldquoWith a cold snap predicted over the coming weeks,duvets are only going to become even more inviting. At least Brits are taking measures to reduce the struggle, by planning ahead and setting their heating to come on before their alarm.

title: musselburgh-swimming-pool-shut-all-evening-after-faecal-incident
story: A spokeswoman for enjoyleisure, which manages the facility, said: "Regrettably we had to close the pool at Musselburgh Sports Centre on Monday at short notice around .pm."This was following a faecal accident."In line with our protocols and health and safety requirements, the pool was closed in order to complete a full treatment cycle."We fully appreciate the frustration and disappointment this closure caused however we also know that patrons will understand and accept this approach is necessary in such circumstances."The spokeswoman said that the pool reopened at am today .A post from Musselburgh Amateur Swimming Club on Twitter said: "Session cancelled ndash tonights session is unfortunately not running today due to an issue at the pool. We apologise for the short notice but this is outwith our control. We look forward to seeing everyone on Wednesday."

title: tranent-teenager-recovering-well-after-horror-skiing-accident
story: An air ambulance brought Nicholas Guest back from Sion on Monday, with the teenager now in Edinburghrsquos Western General Hospital.Older sister Lizzy was delighted her brother was one step closer to being able to come home.She told the Courier: ldquoHe is a lot happier for being back in Scotland. There is a big change in his presentation.ldquoWe are all glad he is back and just along the road now instead of travelling hundreds of miles.Nicholas, , of Tranentrsquos Lawson Way, was placed in a coma following an accident while skiing in the resort of Saas-Fee, near the Italian border, earlier this month.The teenager bumped his head on the ground after going over a jump and underwent surgery, with doctors monitoring his condition.On Monday evening, he arrived back in Scotland and Lizzy, who lives in Haddington, said: ldquoHe is improving little bits all the time.ldquoHe has progressed quite a lot in the last two weeks considering how severe his injuries were.ldquoHe is awake for longer and he speaks a little bit more. He still has issues with his mobility but has been referred onto eye specialists, speech and language, and physiotherapy. He struggles on focusing his eyes a bit.ldquoBeing back in Scotland has made a massive dference just in terms of his mental health.ldquoAs well as his physical health improving, we are trying to encourage him to do as much as he can and we are trying to stimulate him to the maximum and get him recovering quicker.Nicholas plays rugby for Preston Lodge RFCrsquos under-s and was visited by a group from the rugby team in the hospital.A GoFundMe page was set up by Lizzyrsquos fianceacute, Daniel Hunter, to help cover the costs of the family going to visit Nicholas in Switzerland.An initial goal of pound, was quickly surpassed, with more than pound, now collected as the community rallies round.Lizzy said: ldquoWe are pretty amazed.ldquoIrsquom shocked, to be honest obviously we changed the goal when we realised quite a lot of people had donated.ldquoWe thought maybe people would help cover the expenses and it has been incredible.ldquoThat was really helpful and Nicholas appreciates it as well.ldquoIt has been great ndash even people we donrsquot know, friends of friends, that want to help. We donrsquot even know who they are and we are just really grateful they want to help us.Nicholas, who is in S at Preston Lodge High School, Prestonpans, faces a y recovery and rehabilitation period. It remains unclear when he will be able tohome, although Lizzy said her brother wanted to be home within three months.She added: ldquoNow we are going to be focusing on being there for Nicholas.ldquoWe have got our daily lives and jobs to go to but as a family we are all within a reasonable distance.ldquoWe can co-ordinate ourselves to be there at dferent times so he has always got someone with him.Lizzy and Nicholasrsquo mum Marian added: ldquoA great thank you to all who have supported us over the last couple of weeks and those who continue to do so. Nicholas knows about the support and it has had a huge impact on his recovery and wersquore very grateful for this.ldquoI also want to express thanks to all who help and support our family.ldquoThanks to the excellent staff at the Swiss hospital, air ambulance team, and staff at the Western General.To help support Nicholas, go to gofundme support-for-nicolas

title: musselburgh-racecourse-abandons-cheltenham-trials-weekend
story: The racecourses premier jumps weekend fixture had been set to take place this Saturday and Sunday but sub-zero temperatures have put paid to the event, it was announced today.**The @bet Scottish Cheltenham Trials Weekend has been ABANDONED**Unfortunately, due to a frozen track  low temperatures this weekendrsquos Scottish Cheltenham Trials Racemeeting has been abandoned.We are looking to reschedule  more information will follow. pic alVcaiijHarriet Graham, clerk of the course, said: ldquoVery sadly we have had to abandon our Scottish Cheltenham Trials weekend because of frozen ground.ldquoWe have tried really hard to get this meeting on, putting fleeces on the whole course, but unfortunately with temperatures as low as - last night and the night before, the frost has got underneath the fleece and there is no prospect of temperatures rising enough over the next few days for us to get racing on Saturday or Sunday.ldquoIt is such a great shame as we had a very exciting weekend ahead of us, but we just canrsquot beat the weather I am afraid.Bill Farnsworth, Musselburgh Racecourse general manager, added: ldquoMusselburgh will seek the opportunity to stage an extra fixture which will meet the needs of horses that would otherwise have raced at our bet Scottish Cheltenham Trials weekend.Refunds will be made available and the racecourse will be in contact with all race-goers who have purchased advance admission tickets.For more information, visit the racecourse website and social media feeds.

title: big-backlog-of-500-street-lights-needing-fixed-in-east-lothian
story: Complaints about lights are logged on an interactive map on East Lothian Councilrsquos website, which shows that some were reported as not working as far back as October last year, with the fault still classed as ldquounveried.A senior officer at East Lothian Council confirmed the backlog as he responded to a complaint about lights being left unfixed outside a school.He said that budget cuts had ldquorun down our establishment and the council was unable to recruit enough electricians because it could not compete with private sector salaries.In an email, the senior lighting officer said: ldquoThe council currently has a backlog of some  lighting faults. We are also suffering from a shortage of staff to address the issue.ldquoBudget cuts have run down the establishment and further recruitment has proved unsuccessful, with electricians outwith local government enjoying much higher levels of remuneration than we can offer.Councillor Norman Hampshire, the council administrationrsquos spokesperson for the environment, insisted that the number of faults equated to ldquoless than three per cent of the , lights the local authority operated in the county.And he said that more than half the lights in East Lothian had been converted to LED, requiring far less maintenance.Mr Hampshire said: ldquoIn the meantime, we are continuing to inspect reported faults as quickly as possible and, where a fault is a matter for ScottishPower, we are making sure this is dealt with as soon as possible.ldquoWhere repairs are our responsibility, we have used electrical contractors to assist with repairing lighting faults and we plan to use this resource again when the need arises.Mr Hampshire added that some lights in new housing developments remained the responsibility of developers until they were transferred to the council.The senior officer was responding to a complaint about lights being left unfixed outside Dunbar Primary Schoolrsquos John Muir campus. He confirmed that the council had used contractors in the past but said: ldquoThe high costs involved mean any long-term engagement is unsustainable.Mr Hampshire added: ldquoIn relation to recruitment, East Lothian Council is experiencing the same challenges as other local authorities are as a result of UK growth and we are seeking to mitigate this impact.Among the street lights currently out of action are some at Robertson Drive and Lindores Drive in Tranent due to a faulty cable, with ScottishPower stating work is due to be carried out late next month.Check your street lights on the local authorityrsquos interactive map here.

title: retiring-golf-club-starter-recalls-meeting-neil-armstrong-and-movie-stars
story: A GOLF club starter who once welcomed the first man on the moon to the fairways has called it a day.North Berwick Golf Club bid farewell to starter Sam Fox this week, as he retired after  years of service to the club.As a starter, it was Samrsquos job to set the pace of play on the course, as well as offering his knowledge about both the coursersquos history and hints and tips on how to play it.Sam, originally from Wales, moved to Scotland as a youngster and attended Dalkeith High School he eventually joined the police, working in Musselburgh and then later in North Berwick.Retiring after  years on the force, a friend of his let him know about a vacancy at North Berwick Golf Club.ldquoI started there as a ranger, said Sam, ldquoand pretty quickly they askedI wanted to be their starter.Over his two decades at the West Links, Sam has seen many changes.ldquoThere have been  captains while Irsquove been there, and they seem to be getting younger and younger, he said.ldquoIrsquove worked through the introduction of high-tech computerised systems, elite golf equipment and the golf outfits getting more and more colourful!With North Berwick Golf Club being hailed as one of the best and oldest in the world, Sam has seen his fair share of high-profile golfers and famous celebs.ldquoThe most important customer that I had was the next one who would play ndash everyone gets treated the same, but saying that, I have met some pretty famous people, he said.ldquoI remember Neil Armstrong, the first man on the moon, coming in.ldquoI didnrsquot recognise him at first, and so asked him what he did for a living. He said he was a pilot and I asked himhe flew with Virgin, or one of the big companies. He replied that he usually flew a little higher up than that. It was only then I realised who he was!ldquoIrsquove met Michael Douglas, Sean Connery, and Irsquove recommended good local pubs to Jack Nicholson.ldquoIf someone high profile is coming round, we usually get the call a few days ahead of time. Theyrsquoll make up a name for them so we never know who it is until they arrive. Theyrsquoll say lsquoMr Brown is helicoptering in to Archerfield and will be with you at such and such a timersquo.ldquoThatrsquos when you know itrsquos somebody famous.Sam has been receiving cards and letters from people all over the world at the news of his retirement, thanking him for making their experience at North Berwick memorable.But he said: ldquoI was only doing my job. People pay a lot of money to play at the course and sometimes have booked years in advance and saved up to do so, so itrsquos important to make their time with us as special as possible. We do everything we can to accommodate.ldquoEvenwersquore having to tell people they canrsquot play, maybe because the weather is too bad or theyrsquore not experienced enough, oritrsquos a stag do who are too drunk and have fallen over trying to put the tee down, we do what we can to still make a good experience for them.As for his retirement plans, Sam said: ldquoMy we has a list of things needing doing around the house, so Irsquoll be spending a lot of time at the DIY shop I think! But Irsquove had many invites from golf courses over Scotland to play there, so itrsquoll be nice to have the time to take them up on their offer.Samrsquos we Andrea also works at North Berwick Golf Club in the accounts office and they have been married for  years.Elaine McBride, general manager of the club, said of Sam: ldquoWhat a great servant to the club, who has been synonymous with our visitor experience at North Berwick Golf Club for over two decades. Sam will be missed by staff, members and visitors alike.Sam has been praised on social media, including by Andy Bower, who said on Twitter: ldquoMyself and seven other golfers played a few years ago and before we teed off Sam spent  minutes thanking us for choosing to play North Berwick. Sent us all on our way with a smile on our face.A drinks reception for members and staff to mark Samrsquos retirement takes place at the club at pm on Monday.North Berwick Golf Club is in the process of recruiting a new starter.

title: scottish-seabird-centre-shut-for-refurbishment
story: The Seabird Centre is closed from todayuntil the start of April.The exact re-opening date will be confirmed next month after the eight-week internal refurbishment has been completed.The refurbishment is focusing on reorganising the upstairs of the centre to allow more space and a clear line of sight to the Discovery Centre.The refurbishment includes the addition of exhibits to the Discovery Centre, as well as an internal wall removed and retail and cafe space relocated.The retail area, cafe and toilets will also be redecorated.

title: plan-to-revitalise-dunbars-east-beach-revealed
story: Huge amounts of sand have been lost to the sea in recent years at Dunbarrsquos East Beach ndashwith an unsightly mix of seaweed and rock now dominating the shore.Residents have long called for action to combat the beach erosion and now plans for groynes, a breakwater and rock armour have been drawn up in a bid to reverse the trend.The proposed works, which have been formulated by East Lothian Council, include repairing or replacing an existing groyne on the south of the site that has fallen into disrepair.A rock groyne would be created at the northern end of the beach, opposite the junction with The Vennel, with a concrete groyne towards the south, while a rock breakwater would also be included.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoIt is hoped, by reducing the wave conditions at the beach combined with the refurbished groyne, the bay will retain more sediment and in the long term provide improved protection to the existing sea defence wall and regain the amenity value that has been lost in recent years.The work is split into four sections, with the refurbishment of the existing groyne acting to retain beach level in the area as it is currently.Secondly, the breakwater, in addition to providing direction protection to a limited section of the defence, will allow an assessment of capacity for a natural beach to be developed. It will also advise on any further, long-term solution to the issues at the beach.The groyne at the northern end of the beach will provide protection over part of the northern section of the seawall, with the potential to develop a higher beach in front of the wall.Finally, armour stones will be put in place along Lamer Street to protect the seawall.Discussions on how to revitalise the East Beach, which was once a popular tourist attraction, have been ongoing for more than five years.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, has been heavily involved in the talks to find a solution.She was hopeful the latest measure would help and told community councillors: ldquoThe rock breakwater, the design has been worked on for more than two years.ldquoIt is now the preferred design solution and is the subject of a planning application.ldquoThere has been a lot of chatter about the East Beach and I wanted you all to be aware of what is going on and to be able to speak with some authority.Stones weighing anywhere between three and six tonnes will be used as part of the project, with work expected to take place throughout the summer and into the autumn.Mrs Swan was expecting heavy machinery to be on the site and said: ldquoIt will require big machines, at least -tonne trucks, moving these rocks around.ldquoThe East Beach will be the site of quite a lot of activity over the summer and we are bound to get some negative comments. But, hopefully, people will recognise this is an endeavour to protect the sea wall, which has failed three times in the last year.Ward councillor Norman Hampshire was also at the meeting and was pleased to see steps being taken in a bid to revitalise the beach.He said: ldquoExperts have said this is the best option to accumulate sand in this area but nobody can give any guarantees. It is nature we are playing with and it is whether sand is brought into the area.ldquoThere has been talk about importing sand but the costs are huge and it could be washed away the next day.

title: asbo-issued-to-haddington-woman
story: Natalie Breslin was given an anti-social behaviour order , which will remain in place for two years.The Brown Street resident is prohibited from shouting, swearing, using aggressive, abusive or intimidating language or behaviour within her property or on nearby High Street.Ms Breslin is also prohibited from shouting, swearing, or using threatening, intimidating, aggressive or abusive language or behaviour at a property on the townrsquos Riverside Drive, and of behaving in a manner that would cause or be likely to cause alarm or distress to residents or visitors of the street.Ms Breslin, , is similarly prohibited from behaving in an anti-social manner within North Berwickrsquos Glenburn Road and Lochbridge Road.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoEast Lothian Council will take the appropriate legal action against those who persistently behave in a way that causes alarm and distress to others.ldquoIn this case, our Safer Communities Team worked closely with Police Scotland in collating the evidence used to inform the application to court.ldquoI would ask anyone affected by anti-social behaviour to call the councilrsquos dedicated  hours a day helpline on   .

title: strikes-imminent-at-queen-margaret-university
story: The industrial action is scheduled for next Thursday , next Mondayand next Wednesday .The strikes follow a ballot of University and College UnionScotland members in which  per cent of those who voted supported industrial action on a turnout of  per cent.Those set to strike work in academic and academic-related positions, including the library and student support.The union says the row centres on cuts that would put more than  jobs at risk.It argues that alternatives to the current plans ndash including resource sharing, management savings and extending the period of restructuring ndash have not been sufficiently explored. The local branch is considering its next steps.The university employs  staff.A spokesperson from Queen Margaret University said: ldquoWe are still actively in discussions with both unions, with meetings scheduled for next week, and are hopeful that we can make sufficient progress at these talks to avoid industrial action.ldquoAs always, we will make every effort to minimise the impact of any strike action on our studentssuch action takes place.Mary Senior, UCU Scotland official, previously said that strike action was always a ldquolast resort, adding: ldquoUCU members at Queen Margaret University have made it absolutely clear that they have no confidence in the universityrsquos plans.ldquoThe ballot result is a clear mandate for industrial action and to oppose plans for compulsory redundancies.ldquoAxing  per cent of the workforce would have a huge impact on the student experience and on the universityrsquos reputation.The QMU spokesperson earlier said: ldquoThe university has not declared compulsory redundancies, committing itself to seeking to achieve the required reductions in staff costs voluntarily, and is making good progress on achieving this.ldquoAlong with the rest of the higher education sector, QMU faces financial challenges, with grant funding falling in real terms over recent years and rising costs such as pension and National Insurance contributions.ldquoDespite a positive growth trajectory overall at QMU, with costs increasing faster than our income, we have had to take action to reset the balance and thus ensure we can continue to lead in providing relevant teaching and research.

title: pressure-on-scottish-ministers-to-release-cockenzie-site-report
story: The Scottish Government called in a planning application to build a substation on the former Cockenzie Power Station site last March after the land was bought by East Lothian Council.Now, Scottish Conservatives are demanding the findings of the investigation be made public after they were sent to Ministers in private.South of Scotland MSP Michelle Ballantyne said the decision, which came after months of public hearings and representation, ldquobeggars belief, while ward councillor Lachlan Bruce said people were left wondering what the Scottish Government was doing ldquobehind closed doors.East Lothian Labour MSP Iain Gray has already tabled a motion at the Scottish Parliament demanding a public update on the decision as offshore windfarm company Inch Cape, which put in the planning application to build the substation, begins eight weeks of ldquoinvestigative work there.And East Lothian Council has said it is also considering writing to the Scottish Government, adding: ldquoThe council believes it is important for there to be transparency in the decision-making process.The decision on the application by Inch Cape, which is owned by Chinese state-owned company Red Rock, was taken away from council planners as First Minister Nicola Sturgeon was on an official visit to China last March.Inch Capersquos plans to bring energy from an offshore windfarm onto land at Cockenzie have been criticised by the council and communities for potentially sterilising a large area of land which has the potential to bring over , jobs to the county.The Scottish Government reporter scrutinised hundreds of documents from all sides and oversaw a public hearing in Cockenzie late last year.Her findings have been passed to Scottish Minister but are not being made public at this stage.The Scottish Government said: ldquoAn independent planning reporter was appointed to consider this case, produce a report and make recommendations in order for the final decision to be taken by Scottish Ministers.ldquoThe reporter has submitted her report and recommendations on the proposal and a decision will be made in due course.A council spokesperson said: ldquoWe understand that the reporterrsquos findings are now with Scottish Ministers, who will now determine the Inch Cape planning application, and that the contents of the report will be made public when that decision is announced.ldquoThe council believes it is important for there to be transparency in the decision-making process. We are considering possible correspondence with the Scottish Government on this matter. The leader of the council has also indicated that he will be writing to express similar concern to the minister.Mr Gray said the decision on the future of the site should never have been taken away from the council in the first place. He said: ldquoIt is of such great importance to the communities affected and the whole of East Lothian that it should have been determined by East Lothian Council and local people.ldquoThe community needs to know what is happening and what the Scottish Governmentrsquos decision will be, which is why I have tabled a question in Parliament asking Ministers to provide an urgent update.Conservative councillor Mr Bruce said: ldquoThe Scottish Government denied the local authorityrsquos right to make a decision on this application in the first place, making the whole process unfair and open to proper local scrutiny.ldquoThe fact that the report still hasnrsquot been released continues to shroud this whole saga in mystery and will leave many local people wondering what the Scottish Government is doing behind closed doors.And MsBallantyne added:ldquoItrsquos incumbent on the Scottish Government to be open and transparent over their decision-making process.ldquoDuring the formation of the report, the public engaged heavily by taking part in public hearings and contributing towards the report. Local stakeholders deserve to know the outcome of the report and, quite frankly, it beggars belief that the Scottish Government have chosen to keep this secret.

title: events-held-in-memory-of-much-missed-footballer-craig-fairgrieve
story: Craig Fairgrieve was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukaemiain  and passed away in July last year.Now, two fundraising events are taking place to raise funds for Ward  at Edinburghrsquos Western General Hospital.The first fundraiser takes place at Dalkeith Miners Club, with a second event at Cockenzie and Port Seton Royal British Legion just over a fortnight later.Craigrsquos sister Lynsay is among those planning the event in Dalkeith on February .She said: ldquoCraig was a friend to everybody.ldquoHe was very laid back ndashhe was more laid back he would be horizontal.ldquoIf somebody tooted at him in the street he would wave and he liked a bit of banter.ldquoHe was notorious for lines out of films and he was a cheeky chappy and a guy with a smile on his face.Craig, of Prestonpans, played football for Tranent Juniors under-s after growing up in Macmerry and going to Ross High School in Tranent.He began to feel unwell towards the end of .His we Amy said: ldquoIt all started with tiredness. Craig was going to work and coming home absolutely exhausted.ldquoWe thought this was not normal and he got sent for blood tests.ldquoThat was when we discovered it was leukaemia and he started treatment at the Western General Hospital.Craig, who was just  when he passed away, underwent chemotherapy and a stem cell transplant as part of his treatment.Positively, he was told the condition was in remission and he was released from hospital, getting engaged in October .However, the leukaemia ed and Craig and Amy tied the knot in the Capitalrsquos hospital on July .Amy said: ldquoHis final wish was to get married.ldquoThe ward was really, really good and got it together. I was given a wedding dress from one of the nurses they were brilliant.A raffle and auction will be held at the first fundraiser, with prizes ranging from football tickets and golf vouchers to hair and beauty and bootcamp vouchers all up for grabs.Music will be supplied on the night by a DJ and Lynsay, , explained why the event was taking place outwith East Lothian. She said: ldquoA lot of the East Lothian venues were just too small.ldquoWe tried to keep it in East Lothian but we are looking for  tickets to be sold.ldquoThe tickets are out there and we are pretty much down to the last  or .Money raised on the night will go to the haematology wardat the hospital.Ahead of the event, more than pound, has already been raised. Meanwhile, the second fundraiser, on March , is a drag queen evening and disco.Amy said: ldquoThat is the sort of person Craig was ndash he was always up for a laugh and all about a good time.For ticketsto the fundraiser in Dalkeith, contact Kayleigh Szymanski or Dave Forsyth, and for tickets to the fundraiser in Cockenzie call Charles Brown on  .To make a donation, go to justgiving crowdfunding craig-fairgrieve

title: port-at-old-power-station-site-could-cost-same-as-new-school
story: A conference hosted by Prestonpans Community Council heard that building a cruise port could prove cost effective for East Lothian Council, which owns the land,it were then leased to port operators.Transport consultant Roy Pedersen, from Port of Copenhagen, told a gathering of councillors, officials and interested parties that a similar project in his homeland had been successfully introduced at a cost of pound million.And he said that the cruise ship terminal at Visby was built by its local authority and then leased to a private company for  years in a move which would repay most of the capital cost.Prestonpans Community Council, which is promoting the idea of a cruise ship port at the former Cockenzie Power Station site, said the Copenhagen example showed how it could work.Urging East Lothian Council to take the idea forward and investigate its potential, they said in a statement: ldquoSuch a capital cost does not seem so very dferent from the cost of building a school and would repay for itself over time under a lease arrangement with the public sector retaining ownership.The conference wasaddressed by community councillor Calum Miller, who told the invited audience: ldquoThere is a huge untapped potential for businesses across East Lothian, the creation of a hospitality college, re-stocking ships with local goods and produce, as well as the income that could be generated for the council from port fees.The meeting, in Prestonpans last Friday, had been criticised by some members of neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton community who oppose the port.It is understood at least one resident wrote to the local authorityrsquos chief executive expressing concern that officials would be attending the meeting and calling it ldquoa grave mistake to do so.A council spokesperson said: ldquoIt was entirely appropriate for council members and officers to take up invitations to attend. The seminar event consisted of presentations around cruise and port potential for the site.East Lothian Council produced its own masterplan for the site, which is described as a vision document, but plans are on hold as the outcome of a planning application to build a substation on the land is decided by Scottish Ministers.The council said a series of spring lsquoengagement eventsrsquo were planned for local communities to discuss the future of the site.

title: north-berwick-artists-exhibition-based-on-medication
story: NORTH Berwick artist Andrew Guest is displaying his medicinal artwork in his local pharmacy for a week to make a statement about peoplersquos relationship with tablets and medicine.A series of clay pots cast from the box of every piece of medication that Andrew took between  and , including everyday tablets such as paracetamol and ibuprofen, as well as the first types of tablets he took after being diagnosed with Parkinsonrsquos disease, are displayed in the window of Smithrsquos Pharmacy on High Street.The -year-old moved to North Berwick in  and, after a career as an exhibition officer putting on displays of other peoplersquos art, decided to make his own, completing courses in ceramics at Gateshead before studying pottery in Edinburgh.ldquoIrsquove always been interested in recycling and waste materials, especially pill packaging, he said.ldquoI just started making each box in clay, one for each pot, and it started there really. Itrsquos fascinating, and so much fun plasting and casting objects.ldquoI find a real beauty in the ordinary. I canrsquot paint some unique and beautul scene, but I can create something that people see everyday, and give them a chance to see it in a new light. It is also a picture of one personrsquos dependency on this method of treatment.Sheila Pearson, sales supervisor at Smithrsquos Pharmacy said: ldquoItrsquos generated some interest. People are stopping and looking and taking notice. It seems to be a positive reaction so far.The exhibition is on show at the pharmacy until Sunday.

title: tims-tales-the-senseless-feud
story: MOTORISTS speeding home from work from Edinburgh on the A may sometimes notice an old beehive-shaped doorsquocot on their left soon after they pass the junction for Wallyford and just before the first junction for Tranent.The doorsquocot is surrounded by a crumbling ancient wall. The doorsquocot is a clue that once a residence of some signicance stood here. It was called Dolphingstone Castle. Nothing now visibly remains of the castle, but around  years ago ruins were still to be seen.It was at one time an elegant mansion, but before that, on the same site, an older castle once stood ndash now all gone, and the structures of modernity are hemming in what is left of this ancient site. A wave of new housing laps at its walls to the west, the A traffic roars past on its south, and roads surround it on other quarters.One wondersthis small slice of East Lothian history will survive the developers. I hope it does. It is a small, historic fingerprint and gives a mysterious glimpse into our countyrsquos past, in an area now being carpeted with thousands of new houses.Earlier maps suggest that Dolphingstone Castle was surrounded by woodland. So perhaps the planting of a small wood or orchard within the old walls could create an island of both nature and history amidst the tide of urbanising development in this area.Up above on the ridge of Falside Hill to the south, the restored Farsquoside Castle looks down on the developments below . It sits like an eagle perched on a high ridge, observing the land below.How dferent the landscape it surveys would have been in  when, according to an old story, a small force of hand-picked warriors descended from the castle under the cover of darkness.It was just past midnight when they left, guided by a slither of moon. It was a raiding party, bent on revenge and heading for Preston Tower in what is now Prestonpans.Tradition tells us a feud had existed between the houses of Farsquoside and Preston for some years. The cause of the feud was the breaking down of walls between the two estates and the animals of each side grazing on the land of the other. Regular, and sometimes violent, clashes had taken place.But then Hamilton of Prestonrsquos livestock had been poisoned, or so it seemed. They had drunk from a burn which flowed from Farsquoside and it was assumed the water had been deliberately poisoned. Hamilton of Preston Tower, making no investigation, sent his men on a raid of violent retribution.Farsquoside Castle was attacked and blood was shed. This was the act which the select band of warriors who had set forth from Farsquoside were to avenge.In darkness, they filed down from the ridge on a path now known as Whinney Loan. This took them down to where the new houses are now being built on the southern edge of Wallyford.From here, great care was needed lest they be seen or heard. Dolphingstone Castle lay ahead and although their grievance was not with the occupants of Dolphingstone, early discovery could ruin the element of surprise.So the raiders veered north of Dolphingstone, by way of Prestoungrange, and at dawn, with the smell of the salt pans in their noses, they set about their vengeful work.Screams and running bairns alerted the occupants of Preston Tower. Armed men were ready, for this raid was expected, although not from this direction.The walls of Preston Tower held the attackers at bay but the people of the village suffered the worst of the slaughter. What senseless violence: neighbours separated only by the brae of a hill had been whipped up into a hateful frenzy against each other. Gradually the raiders melted away, back up the hill, with blooded swords.But hate builds on hate and the reckoning was not slow in coming. The very next day, Hamilton of Preston led a force westwards. It arrived by the walls of Dolphingstone Castle and then rounded past them to head up the hill towards Farsquoside, crossing where now the A speeds by.No attempt at surprise was required, this was to be an open fight. The Lord of Farsquoside had arranged his men along the top of the ridge, looking down on the approaching force of Hamiltonrsquos men. The order to charge was given and the men of Farsquoside poured down the slope.The leaders of both sides were in the thick of the fighting. It was the Lord of Farsquoside who fell, pulled from his horse and hacked to death by Hamiltonrsquos men.Seeing the death of their leader, the men of Farsquoside fled back to the castle. But the Lady of Farsquoside, in shock and rage at the death of her husband, rallied the men. She led them out of the castle in a furious charge as the sun began to set, forcing Hamiltonrsquos men to flee back to Preston.The battle, or skirmish as some would call it, was over, and the feud had reached its bloody climax. Soon after it was discovered an infectious disease had stricken the cattle, not poisoned water. Cattle on both sides had been equally affected. No one was to blame.How easy it had been to make enemies out of neighbours based on  assumptions. We are told Hamilton attempted to make amends. But the dead could not rise and the Lady of Farsquoside was said to be devastated at the loss of her husband. We can be sure others of lesser status suffered no less.This feud was over little remains to record it except tradition passed down, captured and retold by th-century writers such as P MrsquoNeill and Robert Seton, from whose works this account is garnished.Preston Tower still stands in Prestonpans, in a ruined but still defiant state. Farsquoside, much restored, is a visual delight still keeping watch atop the ridge. But only those feint hinds of Dolphingstone Castle remain, most of it lost to time and mystery just like the details of this story.But all the more reason to preserve and value them, I think.

title: betting-businesses-told-to-monitor-gambling-habits-of-people-on-benefits
story: East Lothian Councilrsquos licensing board has approved a new gambling policy which puts the responsibility for policing the risks of betting in the hands of new licensees.Among the issues that new applicants will have to prove they have addressed before being given a licence will be monitoring ldquogaming trends that may reflect benefit payments, ldquoidentying and reporting attempts to launder money on premises and ldquoprotecting vulnerable people and those with gambling dependencies.Approving the new draft policy, which will govern the boardrsquos licensing decisions for the next three years, board members raised concerns about a lack of legislation to stophigh streets in deprived communities becoming lined with betting shops.Councillor Lachlan Bruce, Preston Seton Gosford ward member, called for current laws which prevent local authorities from refusing a licence to betting businesses because of overprovision to be changed.He said that it was impossible to walk down some town centre streets without being confronted by gambling premises offering promotions and deals.Mr Bruce told the meeting: ldquoThere are high streets in East Lothian where [betting shops] seem to be every  yards.ldquoThere is an issue where it is impossible to avoid gambling premises.The board was told that the Gambling Act  precluded using overprovision as a reason to refuse a licence for a betting shop.The councilrsquos new policy will put the onus for local risk assessments on applicants who want to open licensed gambling premises ranging from bookies to casinos, bingo halls, tracks and travelling fairs.Board member Councillor Jane Henderson, North Berwick Coastal, spoke of the dangers of gambling addiction, saying: ldquoGambling is an extremely destructive situation and sometime it does not get the headlines other things do.ldquoBut it crosses all walks of le and we, as a board and as iniduals, have a moral duty to recognise it is as much an illness as anything  and anything we can do to help should be taken very seriously.Councillor Willie Innes, council leader and Preston Seton Gosford ward member, cautioned that only a minority of people who gambled were affected by addiction and for others it was simply an activity they enjoyed.He told board members: ldquoWhen I first joined the council, gambling was a backstreet activity with premises down back alleys and it took us a long time to persuade the industry to come onto the high street.Mr Innes said that the new policy, which set out additional risk assessment requirements for applicants, sent ldquoa clear message to both the industry and those concerned about it.

title: prominent-cockenzie-campaigner-larry-tomlins-remembered
story: Larry Tomlins, who was chairman of Cockenzie West Tenants and Residents Association, was involved in campaigns to reduce speeding and upgrade local park facilities in his community.The grandfather-of-two was an active supporter of the recent fight to implement speeding restrictions outside new housing at The Chimneys, Cockenzie, and helped oversee the trial and subsequent introduction of  miles per hourspeed limits in the Whin Park area of the village.Mr Tomlins, , grew up in Ayrshire and moved to Cockenzie more than  years ago, where he raised his family with we Ann.A consultant engineer, he ran his own successful business and still found the time to be an active member of his local community.He was a founding member of the tenantsrsquo and residentsrsquo association, which helped improve Whin Park for local families.Ward councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell said: ldquoLarry made a huge contribution to the tenantsrsquo and residentsrsquo association and the wider community. He understood and clearly articulated the interests of local people. He will be sorely missed.Laura Bishop from the campaign to reduce speeding at Avenue Road, outside The Chimneys, said: ldquoLarry was a lovely man who helped us with our campaign to make Avenue Road pelican crossing safer for the children using it to cross to get to school.ldquoSending condolences to his family.Mr Tomlins is survived by his we, his four children, his daughter-in-law and his two grandchildren.

title: haddington-florist-celebrates-40-years-in-bloom
story: Erica Muirhead opened her shop Ericarsquos on January , , becoming a key part of Haddingtonrsquos High Street.The business celebrated the th anniversary with Prosecco and cake and the owner said: ldquoIt does not seem like  years ndash it feels about ! When you look at it in black and white, it seems absurd.The business was originally based at  High Street before moving to its current home of  High Street in the early s.But Erica, who lives in the town, said her passion for flowers went back to before starting the business.She said: ldquoMy mum loved flower arranging and I used to go to the Haddington Floral Art Club.ldquoI would chum her along and I just really enjoyed it and I was fascinated with all the flowers and plants.ldquoWhen I got a job with Irene Spray, I found something that was just so interesting and every day was dferent in the shop.Looking back over the  years, Erica said much had changed, with a greater iety of flowers now on offer.She added: ldquoI do still enjoy coming in each day.ldquoI am very, very fortunate that I have got something that I love getting up for and out to in the morning. I love the customer contact and just the connection that you form on such a personal level.ldquoFlowers are sent for so many dferent occasions and it is just a lovely thing to be able to touch peoplersquos lives in that way.

title: dunbar-schoolboy-theo-foster-to-run-out-with-scotland-stars-at-murrayfield-on-saturday
story: Match mascot Theo Foster will run out alongside the Scotland team this weekend against Ireland in the second round of fixtures in the Six Nations.The youngster, who is in P at Dunbar Primary School, will be joined at Murrayfield Stadium by his mum Victoria and dad Andy.His dad, who is a support worker, told the Courier: ldquoTheo is absolutely buzzing.ldquoWe have had to scrape him off the ceiling and mum and dad are both excited as well.ldquoMy nephew Taylor Wilson, who is a great player, plays for Scotland Redsand is going to the match as well.ldquoOn the day, we have got to be there for pm and we meet the ladies that co-ordinate the mascots.ldquoThere will be great fun and they get to meet the players.ldquoObviously, they hold the playersrsquo hands and I have told Theo he needs to try to get [Scotland captain] Greig Laidlawrsquos hand.ldquoThey walk out onto the pitch, they run out, and he gets a Scotland tracksuit and top.ldquoThey will stand there for the national anthems giving it laldly before sitting with us in complimentary seats.ldquoAfter the final whistle, he will get autographs from the Scotland players and maybe the Irish players.Theo has been playing rugby since he was in P after linking up with Dunbar RFCrsquos youth system.The budding scrum-half, who lives in Dunbar, was part of the team that won the P  Cup, with the final played at Murrayfield during the clash between Edinburgh and Glasgow Warriors during the festive period.His dad said that the -year-old had tried his hand at football, karate, taekwondo and golf but found a real love for rugby.The names of youngsters at Dunbar RFC were put into a hat and it was Theo who had the luck as his name was pulled out in draw to find a mascot.David Wilson, chairman of the club, wished the family well for the match, which kicks off at .pm on Saturday.He said: ldquoIt is really good, it is a cracking thing.ldquoI know the last kid that did it thought it was really good.

title: strike-going-ahead-as-planned-at-queen-margaret-university
story: That cames after the University and College Unionsaid thattalks with QMU had"ended without a satisfactory resolution".If the dispute cannot be resolved then staff are due to walk out again on Monday and Wednesday next week.UCU members say tehy are are angry at the loss of about  jobs, which represents a loss of seven per centof the universityrsquos total workforce.The union argues thatthese job losses were unnecessary and will increase the workloads of remaining staff who will need to do more with less resources.In the recent strike ballot, two-thirds of UCU memberswho voted backed strike action on a turnout of  per cent.Oonagh OrsquoBrien, QMU UCU spokesperson, said: ldquoNobody wants to take strike actionbut the way the decisions to make cuts were made has angered staff and risks damaging the universityrsquos reputation and the student experience.ldquoThe level of support for strike action shows the strength of feeling about the cuts."The university needs to recognise how unhappy staff are and work with UCU to sort out a mess theyrsquove created.A spokesperson from Queen Margaret Universitysaid: ldquoWe advised all staff and students on Monday that we have reached a position where we have been able to achieve the level of cost savings required from the universityrsquos transformation project without the need to make any compulsory redundancies."We are pleased that, as a result of this, Unison agreed to withdraw planned strike action, but are disappointed that another trade union, UCU, has decided to proceed with strike action today .ldquoWe plan to operate classes as normal as far as possible today and on other proposed dates, and to minimise any disruption to students. Indeed, many of QMUrsquos staff are not members of UCU.ldquoUCUrsquos action is in response to the universityrsquos transformation project plans, which are designed to ensure that we can continue to lead inproviding relevant teaching and research, and in providing the supportive and stimulating learning environment of which we are so proud."The transformation project plans take account of extensive consultation with staff and trade unions over a number of months, and reflects their input wherever possible.

title: roadside-services-plan-for-former-raceland-site-approved
story: More than  jobs are expected to be created when Euro Garages opens its new service station on the site of the former Raceland karting centre, near Gladsmuir.And the company pledged to employ local people who were able to ldquowalk or cycle to work easily on the new development.It includes a -hour petrol station and fast food drive-thru, with additional fast food and coffee shop drive thrus open daily on the site.In a planning statement to East Lothian Council, Euro Garages stated that the site would be its first development to include a McDonaldrsquos franchise in it after creating a partnership with the burger chain.But at the start of the planning committee meeting where the plans were being decided on Tuesday, Euro Garages asked for the statement to be amended, stating they ldquodo not name brands at this stage.The international company has  Starbucks,  Burger Kings,  Subways and  Greggs bakeries already operating out of its sites across the UK and around the world.Tom Jeremiah, group planning director at Euro Garages Group, said: ldquoWe take our responsibility to local employment seriously and this development could deliver up to  jobs in a range of full and part-time roles.ldquoWe aim to employ people who can walk or cycle to work easily, prioritising local people and creating jobs for residents of East Lothian. This will support the local economy and ensure people donrsquot need to travel to Edinburgh to access employment opportunities.At the meeting, concerns were raised about a decision not to provide lorry parking at the site, despite offering lorries refuelling stations.Rob Buffham, Euro Garages planning manager, told the meeting: ldquoOur experience of other sites is HGV parking comes with a lot of problems. Local constabularies want CCTV and security fencing.ldquoIt is recognised by police these days that they are a focus for crime so we are not providing it.Councillor Norman Hampshire, planning convenor, raised concerns about the lack of a lorry park, pointing to the next stop point on the journey south at Asda, Dunbar, where there are also petrol filling services and a McDonaldrsquos.Mr Hampshire said: ldquoWe have problems with HGVs at the McDonaldrsquos at Asda where they park all over the place. We need to find a way for them to park safely without causing hazards to anyone .Councillor Sue Kempson said that while she would support the planning application, she was ldquovery upset about the attitude to the HGVs. She said: ldquoThere is an attitude of lsquowe do not want themrsquo ndash well you are going to get them.Mr Buffham highlighted that an access road leading to the pumps for HGVs had space for lorries to queue on the site.Euro Garages has already agreed to set aside part of the site which may be required to widen the country road to its east to serve the new Blindwells settlement planned for the area in the future.Mr Jeremiah said: ldquoThis is an important development for East Lothian and we are thrilled the council have approved our application.ldquoThere are only limited roadside services on this stretch of the A, and existing services are dated. They cannot offer the modern requirements motorists now demand, including electric vehicle charging points along with high-quality drive-thru retail.Mr Hampshire hoped that part of the land would eventually bring a motel to the site which he said would complete the services development. The plans were approved unanimously, with conditions added to increase the number of bicycle parking spots from  to  to accommodate large groups and ensure construction traffic only entered the site from the A access.

title: works-starts-in-belhaven-on-scotlands-first-surf-performance-centre
story: Coast to Coast Surf School was given the green light to open a lsquosurf hubrsquo on Belhavenrsquos Shore Road last May.Construction work on the building, which will be used by a number of community groups, got under way last week.Alasdair Swan, finance director for Belhaven Surf Centre, said: ldquoWork has now started. We are hoping that the building will be completed in mid-summer but like all these projects it is weather dependent. We are expecting to be open before the autumn.The two-storey building, which is expected to cost in the region of pound,, with funding provided by Leader, WREN, East Lothian Council, Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership, BeGreen, Community Wind Farm and private donations, is the first of its kind in Scotland.As well as providing a home for Coast to Coast Surf School, it will be utilised by a number of other groups, including East Lothian Countryside Ranger Service, The Wave Project and Dunbar Surf Le Saving Club.Mr Swan said: ldquoThe surf centre is a community building.ldquoIt is currently not for profit but we hope to move it to full charitable status.ldquoIt exists to support the ious surfing organisations in Dunbar.ldquoDunbar is getting a growing reputation for wonderful surfing but does not have any facility to welcome people from around the world to Dunbar.Downstairs in the building, which measures  metres by  metres, will including a teaching room and small office.Changing rooms, hot showers and storage will also be included, with the upstairs featuring two meeting rooms, which can be used by members of the public.Ward councillor Paul McLennan was pleased to see work starting. He said: ldquoI think it is fantastic, a great initiative and I think you are going to see more and more people there.Ward colleague Councillor Norman Hampshire was similarly pleased.He said: ldquoObviously, there has been a huge growth in the people coming to Dunbar and Belhaven Bay to do surfing.ldquoTo have this facility right on the beach area will be a huge benefit to all surfers coming to that area.

title: measles-cases-in-europe-highest-in-decade
story: While more children in Europe are being vaccinated against measles than ever before, progress has been ldquouneven between countries and inidual countries have some patches where vaccine take-up is low, it said.Some , people in  of  countries contracted measles, the highest number this decade and three times the figure in .More children in the WHO European Region are being vaccinated against #measles than ever before, but too many are still being missed. Years of suboptimal coverage in some countries led to , cases of measles in . https:t.co FSjTnMqxpv #ImmunizeEurope pic mssFkRzzZmdash WHO EuropeFebruary , It is also  times a record low recorded in .A total of  children and adults died in  following infection, the WHO said.In England and Wales, Public Health Englanddata shows there were  cases of measles between January and October  ndash the most recent data available.Ukraine reported the highest number of measles cases last year across Europe, while more than% of cases were in  countries, including France, Italy and Greece.Dr Zsuzsanna Jakab, WHO regional director for Europe, said: ldquoThe picture for  makes it clear that the current pace of progress in raising immunisation rates will be insufficient to stop measles circulation.ldquoWhile data indicate exceptionally high immunisation coverage at regional level, they also reflect a record number affected and killed by the disease.ldquoThis means that gaps at local level still offer an open door to the virus.The  surge in measles cases followed a year when European countries achieved their highest ever estimated coverage for the second dose of the measles vaccination ndash % ndash the WHO said.Some % of children received the first dose of the vaccine.

title: glasgow-airport-rail-link-to-be-ditched-for-rapid-shuttle-pod-to-paisley
story: A Personal Rapid Transit shuttle pod between Glasgow Airport and Paisley Gilmour Street has emerged as the likely alternative to a full tram-train rail link.Following a meeting between Glasgow and Renfrewshire council leaders, the Transport Secretary and Glasgow Airport yesterday, it has been agreed to work on a business case for the Personal Rapid Transit system.It would see passengers board the pods like ones used at Heathrow Airport to take them to the station at Paisley where they would catch existing services to Glasgow and where.AYE OR NAW, MICHAEL :Our message to transport secretary amid fresh fears over airport rail linkThe final choice will be between the tram-train option and the Personal Rapid Transit pod.It is, however, likely that the rapid transit option will be the preferred one and the option taken forward.The tram-train link hit problems following a study that said it would impact negatively on other services in the West of Scotland and on Central Station which is at capacity.The Evening Times message to the transport secretary earlier this monthSusan Aitken, leader of Glasgow City Council, said: ldquoImproved connectivity to Glasgow Airport is a key priority. However, the advice from officers and consultants is that signicant questions remain about the deliverability of the current tram-train option, particularly in relation to capacity at Central Station.ldquoAs a result, the Executive Steering Group has agreed additional work should be done to establish an alternative Outline Business Case for a Personal Rapid Transitoption.ldquoThis work was not advanced by the previous City Deal Cabinet, but it is now crucial in order to allow us to make a fully-informed choice about which of the options in front of us should be progressed.:Glasgow Airport rail link saga has dragged on for far too longldquoI remain committed to a solution that delivers improved public transport connectivity to Glasgow Airport - but I am determined it should also provide value for money for the city, and deliver the widest possible inclusive economic benefits.ldquoIrsquom confident we have made signicant progress towards that outcome today.Glasgow Airport said congestion on the M means action is needed and ldquodoing nothing is not an option.Mark Johnston, managing director at Glasgow Airport, said: ldquoWe were informed that, due to issues around rail capacity, the project partners are developing an alternative option.: Half a million to go on addressing airport rail link fearsldquoThis will be evaluated and we will, of course, work with the partners to promote the delivery of an effective solution within the agreed timescale.It has been understood that transport officials were not keen on progressing the tram-train link from Glasgow Central to the airport.Michael Matheson, Transport Secretary, said: ldquoItrsquos crucial that improving access to Glasgow Airport is balanced with the needs of the regionrsquos existing transport network.ldquoThe Personal Rapid Transit system option potentially meets this aim, and I look forward to seeing the revised business case once itrsquos completed.

title: bp-sees-annual-profits-more-than-double
story: Shares in the oil giant rose % after the result beat expectations, with underlying replacement cost profits - BPs preferred income measure - surging from . billion US dollarsin .Its fourth quarter underlying earnings also jumped % higher to . billion US dollarsas its recent takeover of US shale oil and gas assets from BHP Billiton offset a drop in oil prices at the end of last year.BP completed the . billion US dollarBHP shale deal at the end of October.Bob Dudley, group chief executive of BP, said: "We now have a powerful track record of safe and reliable performance, efficient execution and capital discipline."And were doing this while growing the business - bringing more high-quality projects online, expanding marketing in the downstream and doing transformative deals such as BHP."He added: "Our strategy is clearly working and will serve the company and our shareholders well through the energy transition."The FTSE  stalwart has been riding the wave of a rebound in the cost of crude in recent years, as has rival Royal Dutch Shell, which last week reported its best annual profits haul for four years.But BP has also been embarking on a number of new projects, which have been boosting production and are helping counter the recent easing off of the oil price rally.The price of Brent crude has fallen sharply from four-year highs of nearly  US dollars a barrel in the autumn to about  US dollars due to concerns of a slowdown in demand as global growth eases, combined with rising inventories.BP bosses have recently said they believe oil prices will now remain steady at between  and  US dollars a barrel.On a reported basis, BPs full-year profit rose to  billion US dollarswhile fourth-quarter results showed it swinging to a . billion US dollarprofit from a  million US dollarloss a year earlier.The group made another . billion US dollarsof payments in  for the  Deepwater Horizon tragedy, which killed  workers and sparked one of the biggest environmental disasters in corporate history.BP s total bill for the Gulf of Mexico oil spill has reached  billion US dollars- but the group recently announced plans to pump , more barrels of oil a day in the region.Full-year results also showed it made estments of . billion US dollarsof assets and the group announced plans to complete more than  billion US dollarsover the next two years.BP said it expected recent major projects to ramp up production in  as its pipeline of new projects around the world bear fruit.It confirmed fourth-quarter shareholder idend payments of . centsa share, up .% on a year earlier.Nicholas Hyett, an equity analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown, said: "What stands out about BP at the moment is its pipeline of new projects around the world - the benefits of which we have seen in ."That is showing little sign of slowing, and with the group also dabbling in renewable and green technologies, BPs got its eyes set firmly on the future."

title: revealed-the-scottish-hmv-stores-set-for-closure
story: Fopp on Byres Road in Glasgowrsquos west end is one of three stores in Scotland which will close after HMV was acquired from administrators by Canadian firm Sunrise Records and Entertainment.The HMV stores in Ayr and Braehead are also among the  stores which have been earmarked for closure. Administrators at KMPG said the closures will result in  job losses.Sunrise, which has been owned by Doug Putman since , has acquired  HMV stores out of administration, securing nearly , jobs in the process.Tenstores in Scotland have been saved, including eight outlets trading as HMV and just two as Fopp ndash the Union Street branch in Glasgow and the Fopp outlet on Edinburghrsquos Rose Street. The HMV stores to have survived are in Aberdeen, Dundee, East Kilbride, Inverness, Livingston, Stirling, Glasgowrsquos Argyle Street and Edinburghrsquos Ocean Terminal shopping centre.Thank you for all of your kind words on Twitter over the past few weeks, sorry we have been a bit quiet.Unfortunately weve had to say goodbye to some amazing people today. Thank you for your dedication  passion over the years. We will miss you. pic OxNBTxSFThe deal marks the second time HMV has emerged from administration, with previous owner Hilco Capital snapping it up following its first failure in .

title: neil-cameron-we-dont-need-neutral-referees-just-better-ones
story: Rangers were in the lead back in August. Remember up at Pittodrie, after the very first game, when Steven Gerrard bemoaned the lsquoworld being againstrsquo his club. Later on came the suggestion Willie Collum was biased, and not in favour of the famous Glasgow. It was a strong case. Or not.But then Neil Lennon claimed Hibs played against  men in a defeat at Celtic Park referee Don Robertson being the extra man.Motherwellrsquos Stephen Robinson wanted officials to go full-time so they could do their jobs properly Steve Clarke has been a constant critic of our men in the middle, while Craig Levein is, well, Craig Levein and loves a moan.Derek McInnes was furious with Andrew Dallas who awarded Celtic a penalty in the League Cup Final for a handball that wasnrsquot a handball which wasnrsquot inside the box but the Aberdeen manager has been knowns to take a pop and his chairman, Stewart Milne, didnrsquot hold back this season when he spoke of the ldquoserious issues surrounding referees.And then came last weekend and those four penalties at Ibrox. Mr Dallas, again, found himself in the centre of a hullabaloo.And to top it all, former ref Steve Conroy insists he was only Jungle Jim among his colleagues, most of the rest were bluenoses, and Tom Boyd, former Celtic captain, insisted ldquoneutral referees must be bought in because our current crop were not good enough and, going by the word he used, biased. Irsquom guessing against Celtic.Ironically, the only one speaking adult was Oran Kearney whose St Mirren team were the ones actually hard done by.And while his players were never going to take a point from Ibrox, that defeat and now a worse goal dference edged them closer to relegation, which will mean sackings and wages being halved. You know. Real stuff.They canrsquot all be right. They canrsquot all be wrong. Andyou look outside the world is still spinning, even after some dodgy decisions which at least gives us all something to talk about. But it feels aswersquove reached rock bottom in terms of how Bobby, Willie, John, Andrew and Steven are viewed.What troubles me still are the less than subtle suggestions from supporters of Rangers and Celtic who have lsquoproofrsquo of mysterious forces out to get them, whether it be Opus Dei or the masons.Oh, and Referee X drinks in the Louden Tavern or Brazen Head. The clubs, incidentally, donrsquot exactly distance themselves with this behaviour.There is a film called lsquoAnyone but Celticrsquo with scenes filmed inside Celtic Park and with a guest appearance from, would you believe, Tom Boyd. You can guess what the plot, pun intended, is.Celtic have won over  trophies, including the last seven in a row. They are one of the most successful football clubs on the planet. Perhaps the film should be retitled lsquoAnyone but Celtic donrsquot win anything in Scotland.rsquoOh, and the idea Rangers are hard done by is laughable. Some of the nonsense which have come by way of the statements shames the club.Right, here goes. The referees in Scotland arenrsquot very good. They are not given enough help by their assistants, fourth official and the SFA. That they arenrsquot allowed to talk in public is a shambles and puts them under even more pressure.The only consistency in decisions made on the park and inside Hampden is that there is gross inconsistency.Every single club believes itrsquos them against everyone . Ask the supporters of Albion Rovers and they will have as many tales of awful officialdom from this season as any those mentioned above.But referees in Scotland are not cheats, which Boyd suggested. However, they need to improve, as do the three colleagues they have with them for Premiership games.If our game is crooked, we need to scrap it and start again. However, these pub bores with an internet  need to prove their accusations with facts. The only fact that counts is human beings make mistakes. Especially when they have whistle in their mouths.

title: Rosemary Goring  Welcome to Brexit Britain  where common sense is rationed
story: People might joke, or talk shamefacedly about buying one or two extra provisions, but as I go around the supermarket, it certainly seems that trolleys are piled higher than usual. Am I simply imagining it, or is the nation starting to lay down supplies, preparing for siege conditions to begin at one minute past midnight on March  Raised in Dunbar, I am well aware that itrsquos possible to withstand outside pressure on the fridge and pantry for longer than yoursquod think. Black Agnes held off the English who surrounded Dunbar Castle for months by eating frugally and arranging for food to be smuggled in by boat. The th-century equivalent of a Tesco delivery, it slipped under the noses of the English in the dead of night.The perils that face us as a no-deal Brexit looms are historic in quite another way. When Britain opted to leave it was a vote, we were told, for that nebulous but comfortingly empowering idea of ldquotaking back control. Now, as the military has been put on standby to impose curfews, requisition buildings, impose travel bans and crush any sign of unrest or revolt, we could not be further from the conceit of taking things into our own hands. Quite the reverse: almost everything is beyond our control, from the fast-rising cost of imported goods and materials, to the foods available to buy, to the terms and conditions on which our new relationship with Europe will depend.The threat to medicine supplies is alarming enough. When food shortages are also widely anticipated then the entire scenario begins to look like the summer of , as the country battened down the hatches, built Anderson shelters, printed ration books, and dug in for the long and gruelling haul. With the Cold War evacuation plan for the Queen being repurposed for our times ndash doubtless a meandering cruise around the outer isles on a yacht, fresh fish daily on the menu ndash it makes you question the wisdom of blind faithin those who run the country.After watching the BBC documentary about David Cameronrsquos appalling European miscalculation that has led directly to this pass ndash rarely have I felt more angry at the arrogance, incompetence and ignorance of our political leaders ndash I begin to think the days of national government in the best interests of all are long since over. Pandering to a narrow clique of troublemaking dinosaurs, all of them cushioned by wealth and power and privilege, is the reason why we are facing destabilising ndash maybe even crippling ndash social and economic uncertainty. What Winston Churchill would say about our present predicament probably couldnrsquot be printed.I have not yet bought so much as an extra jar of coffee, though there was such a terric deal on loo-roll in one shop the other weekend that we staggered home carrying enough bags to face down an outbreak of dysentery. Wersquore safe on that front for a while. To be honest, it feels a bit over-anxious to listen to scaremongering about emptying shelves, like waving a white flag long before all hope of relief has faded. Yet it is probably sensible to be prepared, even though stockpiling has a bad reputation, suggesting panic rather than a strategic emergency plan.Lettuces, apparently, are going to be like gold dust, but of all the problems Brexit promises, this surely is the least worrying. Some in these parts survived without salad their entire lives and lived to be . Now, however, is the day to rue a garden filled with mosses, clematis and jasmine, rather than with drills of potatoes, leeks and root veg, with a henhouse near the door.Just how empty will the shops become  Around where I live, there are so many farms I doubt wersquoll go long without milk, eggs, potatoes or meat. There is more likelihood of cholesterol overload than starvation.But I might be wrong. So what should go into the Brexit bunker  Irsquoll start by buying logs and oil, followed by a few daysrsquo worth of tins, jars and vacuum-packs. Oatcakes by the kilo, plus ground coffee, tea, wine ndash obviously ndash and the sort of butter that only comes from France, which is as good as cheese.On a visit to Umbria, my husband met a man with an allotment who showed him shelves stacked with bottles of home-pressed olive oil and tomato sugo, ready for autumn. He poured a hearty red wine from his vineyard, while overhead, blackening hams hung from nails. Itrsquos hard to think of anything more comforting than to have your own grocery store within a few feet of the kitchen table. To my mind itrsquos the very definition of taking back control.Read more: May must abandon her Brexit kamikaze mission

title: loch-lomond-hires-40000-litter-manager
story: But for decades Loch Lomond has been blighted by anti-social campers and daytrippers who leave litter and refuse in their wake, despoiling the areas natural beauty.Now bosses at the he Loch Lomond  The Trossachs National Park Authority are to open a new front in the war against waste by employing a dedicated Litter Prevention Manager to try to solve the problem.Previous attempts to curb environmental damage such as plastic rubbish, abandoned camping gear and discarded tin cans on the Lochs shores have seen campers herded into dedicated zones, police monitoring laybys and endless information campaigns.But campaigners say that the latest attempt of employing someone to keep a lid on the problem shows that the fight against litter louts is being lost.The park has been hindered by the fact that much of its  square miles is covered by dferent councils who dont have the same litter collecting strategies.:Ten campers reported for breaching new national park lawsFly-tipping is also a huge problem, with burnt out cars, abandoned tyres and other detritus affecting laybys and verges.The job of the Litter Prevention Manager, a post which pays between pound, and pound,, will see the creation of a "joined-up" strategy to deal with rubbish being dumped in the park, a top priorities in the authoritys -Year Plan.Nick Kempe, a member of the executive committee of the Scottish Campaign for National Parks, who also runs the blog Parkswatch Scotland, said he welcomed the appointment but had several reservations.He said: "I think the reason they have employed such a well-paid person is that they are meant to be working together in partnership with local authorities and they have failed to do so for several years."One of the problems is that although they have councillors for the local authorities on their board, they seem to be incapable of getting staff to cooperate."You might raise eyebrows about it being a senior management post, but I suspect what they are attempting to do is try to give some leadership across the local authorities that make up the area."Mr Kempe said one of the main problems was that dferent councils had dferent policies, with some not keen on putting bins in laybys.:Police to tackle long-staying layby layabouts at Loch Lomond#"Whats basically happened under austerity is that no-one wants to spend any more money so they all try and leave it to others to clear up the mess. There is quite a big issue around that, and also over flytipping," Mr Kempe said."This is a much wider urban problem. Litter in the countryside is a big issue."A post is not going to do this on its own - it needs political support to make everybody work together and create a workable strategy."The National Park attracts more than four million visitors every year and has some of Scotlands busiest major roads passing through it.In  the Park Authority banned wild camping in a bid to restrict overnight visitors to designated campsites. The scheme was being brought in amid concerns over the impact unrestricted camping, including the amount of rubbish which had been strewn around the Loch.But efforts to cut out rubbish have been in vain, with many areas still marred by trash.
