Dave Morris, a former Director of Ramblers Scotland, said the national park authority had wrongly focused on campers as the cause of the scourge, and believes it is day trippers and those driving through who cause much of the problem."Goodness knows whether the appointment of a Litter Manager on a salary of around pound, pa is going to make any dference," Mr Morris said."In its -plus years of existence this national park has demonstrated that it hasnt a clue about how to deal with litter and is more interested in spending its resources on the persecution of innocent campers than dealing with the real culprits."However, a spokesperson from Loch Lomond  The Trossachs National Park Authority said: "The national park is one of the most beautul places in Scotland but unfortunately litter can be a problem blighting some parts of this outstanding landscape, especially during peak periods.:Plans to ban wild camping from parts of Loch Lomond given green flag#"Addressing this issue is one of our key priorities and we have recently appointed a Litter Prevention Manager who will be responsible for developing a National Park-wide litter prevention strategy, working with partners to drive positive change."Although the National Park Authority is not responsible for collecting much of the litter left in the national park, we are leading a joined-up approach to tackle this issue together."Our new Litter Prevention Manager will play a vital role in helping to work collaboratively with stakeholders throughout the national park to prevent litter spoiling the natural beauty of the area."

title: herald-diary-life-is-full-of-ups-and-down-for-sir-chris-bonington
story: GROWING old, continued. Reader Jack Phillipson from Neilston was discussing Brexit with a friend in a noisy cafe and tells us: "My friend says, What about they Spanish matadors  Theyll need to come round soon or they will lose their market. I was vaguely agreeing but eventually felt I had to say that I didnt understand what matadors had to do with it. Matadors  he replied. Im talking about tomata growers."Get the pipOUR picture of unrecognisable hospital food reminded David Knight: "When I was a junior doctor I experienced much trauma in regard to hospital food ndash mostly finding the canteen shut after I got out of theatre. But the one that stands out happened to me when I was myself a patient. After an accident breaking my thumb, I awoke back in the ward to find the affected limb in plaster and suspended from a drip stand. The other arm was strapped to a board and had an intravenous line running. I was literally handless. The kindly ward orderly told me Id missed dinner but she would find me some dessert. Falling back asleep, I next opened my eyes to a plate on my bed table holding an unpeeled orange. Its the thought that counts."Bowled overAND Catriona Kellock in Alva admits: "As a young student nurse in Edinburgh, many years ago, I was given the job of handing out the meals. One gentleman had not ordered pudding and askedthere was a spare one on another tray. He had seen his neighbour with semolina, his favourite. I found a bowl on another tray and gave it to him. When I came to clear up, he hadnt finished it, saying sheepishly, I really prefer the sweet kind of semolina. I looked at the bowl and realised I had given him boiled potatoes in white sauce. They looked very similar."GetawayTHE SNP is being attacked for giving local authorities powers to levy a tax on workplace parking spaces. It reminds us of the health and safety official at a large Glasgow factory giving a talk and asking staff: "Does anyone know the speed limit in the factory car park " A voice replied: "Depends. Do you mean coming in to work or leaving "Rise and shineSAD to hear of the death of former Radio Clyde breakfast host Mike Riddoch, one of the most clever DJs around, although he hated being in the spotlight himself. He once told an old chum of ours that he didnt like to sound too bright and breezy in the morning as it put folk offthey had just woken up. He added: "The greatest compliment Ive ever had is from someone who once said he liked me because however rough I feel, Mike Riddoch seems to be feeling rougher. Had a skinfulEND of an era, as permission is being sought to bulldoze the O ABC music venue on Sauchiehall Street after the recent fire. More student flats no doubt. We remember when Australian singer Jordie Lane, appearing at Celtic Connections, arrived there to hear a fellow act, and was stopped by a bouncer because he was carrying a banana and was told he couldnt take food in. On a whim he askedhe could check it in at the cloakroom and was told he could. At the end of the show he went back to the cloakroom, and when asked what colour his coat was, he replied "Yellow." The girl knew exactly what he wanted and handed him back his banana.TrumpedUS President Donald Trump has been criticised for giving a lacklustre State of the Union address. As John Rain explains: "Once you pretend that Trump has been kidnapped and is doing ransom videos, his speeches are OK to sit through. You just have to pretend that the, I am being treated well has been edited out."Rocky pathJIM from Shawlands reads the interview with mountaineer Sir Chris Bonington in The Herald this week and comments: "Sir Chris said he had ups and downs in his career. Would he not have learned that this pretty much described the whole job on Day One of mountain climbing school "THOSE WERE THE DAYS - : The striking design of the newest church in Glasgow

title: letters-the-younger-generation-deserve-better-than-brexit
story: Like John Milne , I value my European identity immensely and appreciate the fact that the SNP continues to stand up for Scotlandrsquos choice to reject the xenophobic, isolationist option chosen by those misguided souls south of the Border. I can reassure Mr Milne that I have no intention of giving up my desire for continued membership of the EU. I happen to believe that our broad-minded and geographically unrestricted younger generation deserve a better future than the one currently bequeathed to them by those who seem unable to extract themselves from an imperial past.If it does come to leaving, I suspect that it wonrsquot be long until the cynically-misled, exploited Leave voters will turn on those who led the Leave campaign and rejoin the rest of us in order to be, once again, at the heart of European decision-making.Dave Stewart, Blairatholl Avenue, Glasgow.MARTIN Redfern asksNicola Sturgeon is capable of doing ldquowhatrsquos best for the people of Scotland. That is exactly what she is doing. For the last two years she has put Scotlandrsquos constitutional issues to the side and pushed for Scotland and the UK to remain within the customs union and single market. All and any analysis I have read has given that outcome as being in the best economic interests of the UK and Scotland, but Ms Sturgeon, the Scottish Government and Scotlandrsquos Parliament have all been dismissed with contempt.The May Government is only interested in the Tory party and the DUP. The EU has proved extremely flexible in dealing with Mmember territories in or out of the EU, so it was possible Scotland and Northern Ireland could have had a dferent status to England Wales but was never asked. Indeed it has been reported that London insisted to the EU that Scotland be denied sharing in any dferentiation on offer to others.Mr Redfern advocates for what he calls the ldquoMay compromise: trouble is that Theresa May changes the parameters of her deal on a daily basis. Donrsquot believe me ndash ask her own Tory MPs. It is the Tories who have led us to this clf edge, and it will be the Tories who tip us into the abyss. Scotland voted to stay in the EU but has zero status or leverage within the UK ldquoUnion. Ireland is respected and her interests are being protected in the EU Union. The dference is stark and should be an example to any Scot with an ounce of gumption.GR Weir, Mill Street, Ochiltree.ROBIN Gilmourdraws a somewhat simplistic comparison between Irelands long struggle for freedom from British rule and the UKs vote to leave the European Union.He is correct to state that the Republic of Ireland, over hundreds of years, fought against domination by Britain and eventually won its independence. However, Britains partition of Ireland, designed to keep the bulk of the Unionist population and heavy industry under the UK flag, sowed the seeds for future conflict in the north of Ireland.Our present vexatious issue with the Irish protocol has only arisen because the UKs decision to depart from the EU leaves Northern Ireland as, obviously, thanks to the partition of , the only part of the UK that shares a border with an EU country.The Irish Government and the EU are trying to work together with Theresa May and her Government to avoid future loss of le and conflict in Northern Ireland by ensuring that there is no hard border, now, and in the future.The only obstruction to Britain arriving at a solution at present appears to be from those who see the people on the island of Ireland as an irrelevance and a hindrance to a clean break with Brussels,despite  per cent of people in Northern Ireland voting to remain.Mr Gilmours exasperation displays an age-old condescending British attitude towards the Irish that I had hoped had evaporated into the mists of history. As he himself says, Ireland is an independent sovereign nation on a par with Britain. As such, it must be accorded equal importance and respect.Owen Kelly, Dunvegan Drive, Stirling.Read more: Donald Tusk: Theres a special place in hell for people who promoted Brexit

title: major-13m-facelift-to-restore-glasgow-railway-bridge
story: New Clyde Bridge was built between - as part of the Edwardian expansion of Glasgow Central and links Scotlandrsquos busiest station to the west coast mainline and routes across Lanarkshire, Renfrewshire, Ayrshire and Inverclyde.The A-listed structure will undergo extensive refurbishment and repair works with engineers blasting off old paint, inspecting and repairing the steel beneath, before repainting the bridge in its existing colour scheme.Work will be delivered without disrupting the , trains which cross the bridge each day and the project is due for completion by December .Matthew Spence, Network Railrsquos route delivery director for Scotland, said: ldquoThe work we are doing will ensure this landmark bridge can continue to play its vital role in keeping Scotlandrsquos railway moving for decades to come.Paolo Benedetto, group managing director, Taziker Industrial, said: ldquoTaziker Industrial is delighted to have secured the contract to refurbish the Clyde Bridge in Glasgow.In the past  years we have worked closely with Network Rail in Scotland to successfully deliver a number of refurbishments of key structures and contribute to the continued smooth and consistent operation of Scotlandrsquos rail network.The bridge, which is also known as the Caledonian Railway Bridge, will be refurbished in stages with engineering work starting at the southside of the river later this month.Each section of the bridge will be scaffolded and wrapped in special encapsulation material before an engineering survey is carried out to identy those parts of the steel structure in need of repair. The old paint will then be grit-blasted off, metal repairs carried out and new paint applied.The encapsulation material, which has also been used on the Tay and Forth bridge refurbishment projects, will ensure dust and debris from the work remains inside the work-site and does not contaminate the river below.

title: glasgow-signs-off-548m-equal-pay-deal-with-16000-workers
story: Last month council leader Susan Aitken reached an agreement in principle with the representatives of the female-dominated group of claimants, with the councilrsquos City Administration Committee meeting to ratythe final agreement today.Ms Aitken said she was "delighted to have won backing for a deal that finally delivers pay justice for thousands of women in our workforce".:Glasgow City Council confirms poundm equal-pay settlementldquoWhen I became council leader in , I promised Irsquod bring to an end more than a decade of inaction on equal pay," she said.ldquoA year ago, we began negotiations and, today, the council formally agreed a plan to pay women at Glasgow City Council what they are owed.ldquoThat starts to put right a wrong that has damaged the council, its workforce and the city for too long.ldquoI want to thank the women for their determination,their dedication to the city and its people, and for trusting me to deliver what they have always deserved."The women are expected to start receiving their payments, which will average pound, and could be as high as pound,, in June.Since the deal was announced on January  almost , additional claims have been filed, bringing the total number of claimants to close to ,. The vast majority of that number is made up of female caring, catering and cleaning staff although a small number of men, including  janitors, is also included.While it was not initially clear whether the council would accept the most recent claims, it is understood that it agreed to do so yesterday, clearing the way for the deal to be signed. Had the agreement not been reached the matter would have ed to the Employment Tribunal later this month, with a hearing scheduled for February .The only point that now remains to be agreed between the local authority and the claimantsrsquo trade union and legal representatives is whether the period being paid out for will end in  or , with the council expecting to have a clearer view of how far the poundm will go by next month.It is thought that the authority favours the later cut-off date because, while that would result in larger payments overall, it would reduce the amount of interest it would have to pay on each inidual settlement.How long a period inidual claimants will be paid for depends on when their claim was filed, with Scots law stipulating that such settlements can only be backdated for five years. That means the women filing in the last two weeks will receive just five yearsrsquo worth of back pay while those who filed soon after the councilrsquos unfair pay scheme was implemented in  will receive  yearsrsquo worth.:Popular Glasgow venues could be sold to fund poundm equal pay dealAs the councilrsquos female employees will continue to be paid unfairly for the time being due toits discredited pay scheme remainingin place, a further settlement will be made to all eligible claimants once a new system has been agreed.The council expects it to take at least two years to devise the new system, meaning the later settlement is likely to cover the period from either  or  to .The , potenially eligible womenwho have not yet filed a claim will be able to do solater this year in order to be part of that second settlement.Last week the council released a report detailing how it intends to fund the settlement, confirming that buildings including the Riverside Museum, Glasgow Royal Concert Hall and Scotstoun Leisure Centre will be sold to and leased back from wholly owned arms- organisation City Property Glasgow Investments, which will raise finance against them.City Property willalso refinance a loan taken out in . That is expected to release a signicant sum as a result of the assets the loan is secured against increasing in value over the past nine years.

title: nicola-sturgeon-and-mark-drakeford-release-joint-statement-condemning-no-deal-brexit
story: In a joint statement, the political leader for Scotland, Nicola Sturgeon, and her Welsh counterpart, Mark Drakeford, called on Theresa May to take the no-deal option off the table and put forward legislation to scrap March  as the day the UK leaves the EU.They also called for her to request an extension to the Article  deadline and drop her red lines in Brexit negotiations.The statement said: "We are particularly keen to do so to press home the point that all the evidence we have seen to date suggests that the UK is simply not prepared for a no-deal Brexit in less than two months time.:No deal Brexit would seeof mobile roaming charges"Our firm view is that such an outcome to the Brexit negotiations would be a catastrophe which would cause signicant short-term disruption to the lives of ordinary citizens as well as to businesses and long-term harm to our economy."And while a longer period to prepare for no deal as proposed by some Conservative MPs might reduce the risk of people in Scotland and Wales being unable to access the medicines that they need or the range of foods they want to buy, it would do nothing to mitigate the longer-term economic damage that such a radical rupture with our EU neighbours would cause."The jobs lost at Schaeffler in Llanelli and the cancelled investment at Nissan in Sunderland are just a foretaste of the future. The CBI has estimated a no-deal Brexit could cost the Scottish economy pound billion a year by ."The statement highlighted the House of Commons, Welsh Assembly and the Scottish Parliament have all rejected Mrs Mays deal and her government "appears unable" to identy alternative arrangements to the Irish backstop to enable the deal to pass through Parliament.It continued: "The point has been reached where there is now no time to waste."We therefore renew our call for the Prime Minister to make clear that she and her Government will ensure no deal is taken off the table."This should include putting forward secondary legislation now to remove  March  as Exit Day from the EUAct."The Prime Minister must also request an extension from the EU of the Article  deadline."We call on the Prime Minister to request such an extension immediately to put an end to the threat of the UK crashing out of the EU without a deal in only eight weeks time."The statement concluded: "The EU has made it clear that in terms of negotiations on the future relationship, it would respond favourablythe Prime Minister was to drop her red lines."We therefore further call on the UK Government to abandon those red lines, which the EU has repeatedly said severely restrict the possible outcomes of Brexit.":Donald Tusk: Theres a special place in hell for people who promoted BrexitShadow Scottish Secretary Lesley Laird and STUC General Secretary Grahame Smith also called for the UK Government to rule out a no deal Brexit, in a joint letter to Scottish Secretary David Mundell.Ms Laird said: "With  days left until we leave the European Union, the only thing that is clear is that a no-deal Brexit would be catastrophic for jobs, industries and Scotlands economy."It is shameful that the UK Government still maintains that this an option, and it should rule it out immediately."Mr Mundell said: "I urge the Scottish Government to work constructively with us ahead of our departure from the EU. By working together, we can avoid a no deal Brexit which would be hugely damaging for people and businesses in Scotland."He was speaking ahead of meeting of devolved administrations and UK Government at the Joint Ministerial Council, which he said is part of "extensive ongoing engagement".

title: conference-set-to-hear-how-public-sector-can-improve-its-carbon-emissions
story: Alan Asbury, Director of CLS Energy  Chairman of the Low Carbon Club has been confirmed as a speaker at Low Carbon Scotland , a must-attend event for anyone concerned about the effects of climate change. Titled lsquoDriving the transition to a zero-carbon economyrsquo, itrsquos a unique conference that will address Scotlandrsquos current carbon position and hear from those leading and driving policies and proposals.As Chairman of the Low Carbon Club, Asbury works with event organiser pppto investigate the claims of some of the technology providers that look to the club for endorsement.When technologies look potentially viable, live trials are conducted which are then metered, monitored and measured to prove real le benefits to other Low Carbon Club members. With more than a  years of energy management experience, he is a Chartered Energy Manager and Certied Measurement and Verication Professionalwith the UK Association of Energy Engineers and his input will be valuable at the event, where one of the focuses will be how the public sector can reduce its carbon emissions.The current situation will be highlighted and a discussion on how this can be improved and delivered will play a central part in the conference, with some world-leading technologies, innovations and examples of best practice showcased.Low Carbon Scotland believes the countryrsquos ambitious plans cannot and should not be delivered by government alone and that every household and every organisation have a role to play.LCSrsquoS aim is to enable and support the changes required now as well as stimulating the innovation and creativity required for the future. Tackling climate change is a moral responsibility but also an economic opportunity. Low carbon technologies will revolutionise the global economy and the Scottish Government provides resources such as Climate Conversations and Greener Scotland ndash Letrsquos Go Greener Together ndash to help companies and organisations understand why climate change is an issue and what we can collectively do to reduce our own impacts.And while Scotland is a world leader in tackling climate change and the countryrsquos transition to a more prosperous, low carbon society is already well under way, partnerships between all sectors are vital to overcoming the challenges and in discovering new opportunities to help create the future that we all want for Scotland. Paul Wheelhouse, the Minister for Energy Connectivity and the Islands will once again deliver the keynote address at this yearrsquos sixth annual conference in June at Edinburghrsquos Dynamic Earth.

title: brexit-theresa-mays-demand-to-renegotiate-withdrawal-agreement-rejected-by-eu
story: In a joint statement, the European Commission President stressed the withdrawal agreement could not be changed, as the UK PM wants.But he said the EU was open to adding words to the non-binding future relations document that goes with it.:Brexit latest: Theresa May visit overshadowed by Donald TuskIn a statement talks are set to resume to see"whether a way through can be found that would gain the broadest possible support in the UK Parliament and respect the guidelines agreed by the European Council".:No deal Brexit would seeof mobile roaming charges"Despite the challenges, the two leaders agreed that their teams should hold talks as to whether a way through can be found that would gain the broadest possible support in the UK Parliament and respect the guidelines agreed by the European Council."The Prime Minister and the President will meet again before the end of February to take stock of these discussions."Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay and EU negotiator Michel Barnier will hold talks in Strasbourg on Monday.The statement said Mrs May "raised ious options" for dealing with MPs concerns about the backstop."The Prime Minister described the context in the UK Parliament, and the motivation behind last weeks vote in the House of Commons seeking a legally-binding change to the terms of the backstop."She raised ious options for dealing with these concerns in the context of the Withdrawal Agreement in line with her commitments to the Parliament."Mr Juncker "underlined that the EU will not reopen the Withdrawal Agreement" but "expressed his openness to add wording to the Political Declaration agreed by the EU and the UK in order to be more ambitious in terms of content and speed when it comes to the future relationship".

title: labour-shifting-from-opposition-to-the-facilitator-of-a-tory-brexit-ian-blackford
story: He said:"Jeremy Corbyns confirmation that he will throw support behind Theresa Mays disastrous Brexit deal is a severe blow to businesses, workers and people across the UK who are rightly concerned over the impact of Brexit.:Brexit: Theresa Mays demand to renegotiate Withdrawal Agreement rejected by EU"The attempt by the Labour leader to mask this as anything other than support for a Tory-driven, economy-wrecking Brexit deal is utterly disingenuous."Labour under Jeremy Corbyn has shted from being the Official Opposition to the official facilitator for a Tory hard Brexit that will hit jobs and living standards across the UK."Mr Blackford repeated calls for Theresa May to take the threat of a no-deal Brexit off the table and urged Labour "to work with the other opposition parties in holding this Tory government to account"."It is clear that under every scenario Brexit will leave us all worse off - there is no such thing as a good Brexit," said Mr Blackford."If Jeremy Corbyn is intent on helping Theresa May drag Scotland off the Brexit clf-edge, then it will demonstrate yet again that Scotlands national interests can only be protected with independence.": Brexit latest: Theresa May visit overshadowed by Donald TuskScotlands Constitutional Relations Secretary Mike Russell has accused UK ministers of living in a "fantasy world" over EU withdrawal.Following a meeting of the Joint Ministerial Councilin London, Mr Russell said: "There needs to be a sense of reality in the UK Government."It is like a fantasy world in there. They do not realise the problems they are causing."What it is is an abdication of responsibility."Referring to the JMC meeting, Mr Russell said: "I know no more now than I did when I went in there."There is no indication of what the Prime Minister is seeking to achieve in Brussels because she cant achieve what she says she is going to achieve."I think that we are in an incredibly grave situation with a group of people who, frankly, I wouldnt send for the messages."He added: "The reality of the situation now is that we have to talk very seriously about a no deal because it doesnt seem the people who are charged with getting a deal to know what they are doing."Mr Russell said Article  needs to be extended, stating: "Quite clearly what the Prime Minister should do now, instead of wasting her time talking about things which wont happen, is, first of all seek an extension to Article , which she can do, shes in Brussels."Then she has got to rule out a no deal."Liberal Democrat Brexit spokesman Tom Brake also hit back at the Labour party saying: "Jeremy Corbyn has turned his back on the millions of Labour members and voters who demand a better future than Tory Brexit Britain."He has chosen to forget that Labour conference voted for the party to campaign for a peoples vote after failing to secure a general election."Brexit must not be agreed through a stitch-up between the two old parties. The public deserves a peoples vote with the option to remain in the EU."

title: public-sector-bid-to-run-scotlands-railways-must-be-kept-on-the-table-patrick-harvie
story: Speaking at First Ministers Questions on Thursday, Mr Harvie said that the Scottish Government must consider using a break clause in the ScotRail contract to end Abellios deal in operating the franchise.:ScotRail now beyond a joke after train overcrowding on Six Nations weekendIn November, MSPs voted against a Labour motion calling for a cancellation to the agreement.Figures published earlier this week indicated that , ScotRail services were cancelled due to a lack of staff between April  and January  this year.ScotRail said that the late delivery of trains, coupled with a rest day working and overtime ban last year had contributed to a drop in performance levels.Mr Harvie suggested that devolving control of Network Rail could help to address some of the issues facing rail travel, but urged Deputy First Minister John Swinney Nicola Sturgeon to take action."Theres clearly a need for wider structural change. Many of us would agree that Network Rail needs to be in the control of Scotland so that we can have a truly joined-up approach to these issues," said Mr Harvie."But we cannot wait for that. That is no excuse for not taking action now."Three months ago when many of these failures were already being regularly reported, the Government voted against using the breakpoint in the ScotRail franchise next year."If the Government werent convinced then, I think they should be convinced now that that option must remain on the table."Surely the Deputy First Minister wont rule that option out because doing so would give Abellio a free pass to continue failing."The Government must work on the assumption that a public sector bidder may be needed from next year".Mr Swinney said that the Scottish Government does not consider the performance of ScotRail to be acceptable and reiterated that a remedial notice had been issued to Abellio on December .The notice requires the operator to state how it will address current issues by submitting a remedial plan by Febuary .The deputy First Minister agreed with Mr Harvies assertion that Network Rail should be devolved and said that development work to establish a public sector bid was underway."Under the current UK legislation, the requirement to tender the franchise would still remain which then opens up the possibility, which we have now secured as a Government, to bring forward a competitive public sector bid in that context."Development work is underway about how to advance the concept of a competitive public sector bid. That work is being taken forward by the Transport Secretary in dialogue with David MacBrayne Ltd who weve invited to take forward some of that work."The Government believes fundamentally we have got to have an efficient public rail network that meets the needs of iniduals within Scotland, that acts in the public interest, that delivers services that members of the public are looking for."Thats what our immediate short-term action is focused on achieving and its why were open to developing a competitive public sector bid within the context of the existing UK legislation within which we have to operate."Labour Transport spokesman Colin Smyth said that his party would continue to campaign for public ownership of the railways.Mr Smyth said: "Labour wants a publicly owned ScotRail but our plans to exercise the break clause in Abellios contract were blocked at Holyrood by the SNP and the Tories."With passengers facing rip-off fares and substandard service, well continue to make the case for public ownership of our public transport - unlike the SNP, which has handed Abellio a licence to fail."

title: labour-party-facing-exodus-over-jeremy-corbyns-brexit-stance
story: The Labour leader has written to the Prime Minister setting out five demands that need to be met to get his partys support for a Brexit deal.:Labour shting from Opposition to the facilitator of a Tory Brexit - Ian BlackfordBut Owen Smith, his former leadership rival, said he was considering his position in the party and hit out at the prospect of Labour MPs being asked to back a deal which he said would damage livelihoods.Other pro-EU MPs also criticised Mr Corbyns plan, claiming it was a change to the partys policy of keeping open the prospect of a second referendumLabour couldnt force a general election.Shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer insisted the move by Mr Corbyn did not take the option of a so-called Peoples Vote off the table.In his letter to Mrs May, the Labour leader set out five demands:- A permanent customs union to deliver frictionless trade and help avoid a hard border on the island of Ireland- Close alignment with the single market, including shared institutions and obligations- Participation in EU agencies and funding programmes,- Unambiguous agreements on the detail of future security arrangements, including access to the European Arrest Warrant and vital shared databases.On a visit to Worcester, Mr Corbyn told reporters: "Half of our trade is with Europe. A lot of our manufacturing industries are very frightened, very worried at the moment that on March  therell be a clf edge.:Blow for Richard Leonard as leak reveals , Labour membership slump across Scotland"There cannot be a clf edge. We will do everything we can in Parliament to prevent this clf edge exit."But Mr Smith, who stood against Mr Corbyn in , said he was considering his future in the party."I think its something that I and lots of other people are considering right now," he told BBC Radio  Live."At the moment I may be asked by the Labour Party to row in behind a policy decision that they know, and the Government knows, is going to make the people I represent poorer and - more fundamentally actually - is at odds with the internationalist, social democratic values I believe in."Prominent pro-EU MP Chuka Umunna said the position was "totally demoralising".He said: "This is not Opposition, it is the facilitation of a deal which will make this country poorer."He added: "I hate to think what all those young voters who flocked to the party for the first time in  will make of this."Vote Labour, get a Tory Brexit. They will feel they have been sold down the river."Shadow international trade secretary Barry Gardiner defended the sht in policy away from the six tests Labour originally set for a Brexit deal, saying the offer was made "in a spirit of co-operation and compromise"."Its not about tests now," he told BBC Radio s Today programme. "What we are doing is saying we believe that these are the options that are available that would actually secure a majority in the House of Commons."Sir Keir said the letter "sets out in robust terms that the Prime Minister must abandon her Brexit red lines"."It does not take the option of a public vote off the table."Matthew Pennycook, a member of Sir Keirs frontbench shadow Brexit team, saidMrs May did not accept Labours terms "we must move to support a public vote".There were "no other credible options left" to prevent a no-deal Brexit.:David Mundell fails to sayUK will leave EU on March , only that he wants it toDowning Street confirmed that Mr Corbyns letter had been received, and a spokeswoman added: "We will reply in due course. Our positions on many of the issues in the letter are well known. Our position on the backstop has not changed."The spokeswoman said that no further meeting between Mrs May and the Labour leader to discuss Brexit had been scheduled, but added that "her door is open".Mrs Mays effective deputy prime minister, David Lidington, said the Labour plan for a customs union with a say in EU trade deals was "wishful thinking".In Brussels, a European Commission spokesman declined to discuss Mr Corbyns proposals, saying only: "Our interlocutor is Her Majestys Government and the Prime Minister."On Wednesday European Commission president Donald Tusk highlighted Mr Corbyns "pro-Brexit stance" and said "there is no political force and no effective leadership for Remain".

title: kintore flats plans raise objections
story: Councillors will next week debate proposals for  new affordable flats in the heart of Kintore which have attracted a host of objections.Langstane Housing Association has tabled plans for four property blocks featuring  one-bed flats and six two-bed flats on vacant waste ground on Forest Road.But  objections have been raised on the grounds of insufficient parking and road safety, increased traffic and congestion on Forest Road and the scale of the development and the adverse impact on the amenity.In a report to Aberdeenshire Council’s Garioch Area Committee which meets on Tuesday, director of infrastructure services Stephen Archer says that “on balance” while the development may have an amenity impact on the neighbouring properties, it will fall within acceptable standards.He says: “The proposal for  affordable flats would make a positive contribution to affordable housing provision in Kintore.“It is accepted that any development on this site will alter the outlook from neighbouring dwellings, however, the use of the site for a flatted development is considered compatible with the infill nature of the site and settlement location.”Councillors will be told that the pre-application consultations and discussions during the determination of the application to reduce the potential impact on the neighbouring properties has resulted in the final layout and design.But in its objection, Kintore Community Council slams the proposal, particularly in terms of inadequate parking spaces.Chair Fiona Cooper states: “The proposed parking for the development of  spaces for  residents is insufficient and would result in overspill parking on the oppositie side of the road which would obviously have a major affect on existing residents.”In terms of the scale of the development, the community council recommends a maximum of two-storeys, with Mrs Cooper adding: “The proposed development by reason of size is out of character and would have an unacceptably adverse impact on the amenities of the properties immediately opposite the site and the surrounding area by reason of overlooking and having a visually overbearing impact.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk story: Nominations are being sought to fill  vacancies on Bennachie Community Council.Ideally the Community Council is looking for representation from the settlements of Chapel of Garioch, Culsalmond, Insch, Oyne, Premnay and Rayne.Completed forms must be ed by  pm on Monday, March .An election will only take place on Tuesday, March from . pm and . pm at Insch Institute,nominees exceed the vacancies.The community council’s meeting following the election is due to take place on Monday  March  in the Insch Institute.Nomination forms are now available to collect from the Garioch Area Office in Gordon House on Blackhall Road, Inverurie or email garioch@aberdeenshire.gov.uk.Forms are also available from the Community Council by emailing bennachiecc@outlook.Forms can also be found locally in N S Wilson, Chemist, Insch.For further information about the vacancies please email Alison Cumming Alison.cumming@aberdeenshire.gov.uk or call  .Further information on community councils can be found online here or visit wwwmunitycouncils.scot.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Last years top price animal, a champion heer, sold for #,"  Strong entry of calves for Spring Show viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: playgroup donates nativity cash to charity
story: A north east charity has received a welcome cash boost from an Inverurie playgroup.St Andrew’s Church Playgroup held a Nativity show just before Christmas and the event raised more than £.Through kind donations from parents, grandparents and other family members, as well as cash from raffle sales and refreshments, a total of £, was raised.The playgroup decided to donate the money to Spikin Autism and More , a parent peer support group for families or carers that have children with autism or other disabilities.The group provides a welcoming, relaxed environment for parents to not only share experiences, resources and information to help their children, but also to reduce their own feelings of ‘being alone’ and to provide one another with some much needed supportRepresentatives from the charity visited the playgroup on Friday, January  to accept the donation.Speaking to the Herald, Lisa Moir of SAAM said: “The money will go towards organising training sessions that will provide help on topics including dyslexia, speech and language.“We previously receviedfunding from the Garioch Partnership so we will add this money to that.“We want to help give more people the opportunity to have access to help with childcare issues.“The training sessions are open to everyone and we hope to have day and evening workshops.”Spikin Autism and More is based in Alford but started Peer Support Sessions at Homestart Garioch just over a year ago.Lisa created the group following the death of her husband.She added: “After he died I found it quite isolating finding support to raise our son who was three at the time and diagnosed with autism.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: strong entry of calves for spring show
story: Some of the best commercial calves in the country will be forward at the Royal Northern Spring Show, held in conjunction with Aberdeen and Northern Marts.The annual event, which will be held at the Thainstone Centre on Wednesday, February , has attracted a strong entry of  calves from noted breeders.John and Craig Robertson from Newton of Logierait, Pitlochry, regularly dominate the show and sale, having scooped the supreme championship six times since . Last year, they sold the top price animal at £, for their champion heer and sold three others for £,, £, and £,.This year, the Robertsons have  calves entered including a full sister to last year’s top price heer.Huntly and Insch duo, Blair Duffton and Rebecca Stuart, will alsoto this year’s event with five calves, as will Ian Miller of Miller Farms, North Lurg, Midmar, who has four calves entered.Judging the commercial cattle entries, which will occur following the show and sales of bulls, will be well-known pedigree and commercial producer, Melanie Alford.John Angus, head of livestock at Thainstone, said: “The livestock sale element of the Royal Northern Spring Show is a fast-growing part of the event and we are delighted to be working once again with the Royal Northern Agricultural Society. The Spring Show is now recognised as the number one place for buyers from near and far to come and source quality calves with further showing potential.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"DIGG Councillor Martin Ford"  Councillors keen to prevent cuts viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: wine drinkers could be seeing red over brexit price rises
story: The Journal of Wine Economics featured an industry study that says that the amount customers pay could increase by up to  per cent by  in the event of a hard Brexit, or  per cent in terms of a softer Brexit.British vineyards could benefit however.According to a report by WSTA, the Wine and Spirit Trade Association,  percent of wine drunk in the UK is imported. Of this half is produced in the EU, while the remainder comes from Australia, USA, Chile, Argentina, South Africa and New Zealand. There are concerns thatthe right measures are not put in place it could stop imports from crossing the border, which has lead some retailers to stock up on bottles in advance.The WSTA has been advising members for more than a year that they should increase their stock by  per cent as a starting point in case of a no deal Brexit.Miles Beale, chief executive of the Wine and Spirit Trade Association, said: ldquoSince the Referendum, the WSTA has campaigned consistently for a deal with the EU that delivers frictionless trade in goods, with no additional tarfs or costs.ldquoIf the UK ends up with a no-deal Brexit then wine businesses will have to cope with additional tarfs as well as another duty rise - which is highly likely to end up full square in the consumerrsquos lap, bumping up wine prices to an all-time high.ldquoCurrently there are no tarfs on wines from the EU, Chile and South Africa. A no deal Brexit would result in the introduction of tarfs, estimated to cost UK wine importing businesses over £ million a year.ldquoThe introduction of no deal Brexit tarfs would be a double blow for wine businesses after the Chancellor elected to single out wine for a duty rise at the Autumn Budget.From February  the duty on a bottle of wine went up by p, but add a tarf to the duty rise and VAT and this means an average priced bottle of wine, which today costs £., will cost £. in the event of no deal.Read more: How will Brexit affect your travel plans  This is an extra p a bottle more than consumers paid before the referendum result when an average priced bottle of wine was £..There could be some positive benefits for British vineyards however.It is believed that British wines will seem less expensive than its European counterparts as retailers wonrsquot be forced to hike prices because of rate or tarfs.However, British vineyards could be hit with the lack of skilled workers from the EU and vital agricultural funding streams. data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. He was unable to confirmMeghan would attend along with her husband, but said it would be ldquotruly fantastic for Caithness and help put it on the mapthe royal couple turned up.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will welcome their first child this spring.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Thursday  Feb  : PM

story: Offers over £,ADVERTORIAL: Westermill is an eye-catching period property located close to the centre of Kirkwall. The property is detached and comprises a large entrance hallway,  spacious bedrooms, one with ensuite, living room, dining room, kitchen, shower room, utility room and downstairs toilet. The property benefits from a large enclosed mature garden to the rear of the property and there are also a driveway and shed to the side of the house.The property has oil-fired central heating, together with a fireplace in the dining room and a Morso stove in the sitting room. story: INTERNATIONAL ferry company FRS Group have been revealed as the third bidder for the Northern Isles ferry service.The company, headquartered in Flensburg, Germany, confirmed the news this week.#FRS follows the tender process. title: power cable fault results in rackwick work
story: A faulty power cable, which links Orkney with mainland Scotland, has resulted in work being carried out at Rackwick Bay in Hoy.A Scottish and Southern Energy Networks spokesman said: “SSEN can confirm there is a network fault affecting one of the two electricity distribution cables that connect Orkney to the Scottish mainland. Following a fault investigation process, damage has been located to a section of the Pentland Firth East cable near the shore at Rackwick Bay, Hoy.“There is no impact to customer supplies on Orkney as a result of the fault and contingency measures are in place, including the potential operation of the backup power station at Kirkwall, supported by mobile generation sets, to ensure a safe and secure supply of electricity for customers.“SSEN is committed to ing the network to normal operation as soon as possible and has instigated a repair plan. Following the receipt of the necessary permissions from statutory authorities late last week, work to undertake a sectional cable replacement is now under way.#The statement added: #It is expected this work, which will be contingent on tidal flows and weather conditions, will be complete early next week, with the line re-energised shortly after.“As part of SSEN’s subsea cable inspection and replacement programme, a project to progress an end-to-end replacement of the Pentland Firth East distribution cable is already at an advanced stage of development, with cable installation and commissioning currently due to take place in autumn next year.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: survey project sheds new light on hms royal oak
story: A VOLUNTEER e team has been granted permission to extensively survey the official wargrave of HMS Royal Oak in Scapa Flow.New D photogrammetry techniques are being used and still photography and videography will allow the team to capture and share the spirit of the site.In the early hours of October , , U’s commander Günther Prien guided her silently into Scapa Flow, and launched a torpedo attack, In just a few minutes, Royal Oak was gone.  sailors perished, including over  boy seamen.Ahead of the th anniversary of her loss later this year, a team of volunteer civilian ers has been granted permission to e the wreck by the secretary of state for defence.This is part of a collaboration with the Royal Oak Association and the Royal Navy to document the last resting place of the men who lost their lives, so their passing can be remembered and preserved for future generations.The project aims to ensure that HMS Royal Oak is not forgotten, by sharing imagery with relatives of those lost, as well as the wider public.The survey team is using state-of-the-art underwater imagery techniques, in order to produce high-quality photography and video. In addition, D photogrammetry is taking place so that digital D models of the wreck can be produced. By using these techniques, in essence, the team is able to digitally bring HMS Royal Oak to the surface.Survey organiser and licence-holder Emily Turton said: “The wreck of HMS Royal Oak is the final resting place of  men and boys. As the most intact underwater dreadnought-era battleship, she has an architectural grandeur befitting of any national memorial. However, at the smaller end of the scale, artefacts pertaining to everyday le on board are scattered around the site, bringing home the human story of those lost. The site is peaceful, yet vibrant, and supports a thriving marine eco-system. It is both an honour and a privilege to get to know the site.”Full details and further pictures in The Orcadian this week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: update kirkwall town centre roadworks
story: newsUPDATE: Kirkwall town centre roadworksFebruary ,  at : am vw, px"  Work is set to continue next week on street improvements in Kirkwall#s town centre.There will be further repaving on the area around the TSB bank, on the junction between Castle Street and Broad Street, with a one-way system remaining in place.Orkney Islands Council has said once this initial stage is completed, work will then move to the entrance to Albert Street, meaning the street will be closed to traffic from Laing Street. It#s anticipated this work will start on February  and could take four weeks to complete.The current one-way system means drivers can turn into Castle Street from Junction Road and on into Broad Street but vehicles do not have access from Palace Road into Broad Street.A signed ersion via Clay Loan is in place. In addition, vehicles cannot turn into Castle Street from Albert Street – but can drive on into Broad Street.The works are part of the Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiative’sPlaces and Spaces project, which will see improvements to the area at the bottom of the Strynd, the creation of a new path to the War Memorial at St Magnus and improvements at the head of Victoria Street.The council has said the works at the top of Castle Street will see new paving and road surfacing laid, and the road surface raised to pavement level. This initial phase of the project is due for completion early May after which works will be suspended for the main summer season.Work at the entrance to Victoria Street is set to begin in the autumn, with a suspension planned, in December for Christmas shopping season.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: views sought on cursiter quarry expansion plans
story: Orkney Islands Council is providing a further opportunity for the public to view and comment on plans to expand Cursiter Quarry in Firth.The Council is due to submit a planning application for the long-term development of Cursiter Quarry in Firth this Spring.As part of a -phased expansion plan designed to secure additional reserves the quarry could increase in size over the next three decades expanding into neighbouring fields. The planning application also covers landscaping and future restoration of the site.The application process is being handled by consultants AECOM.The council-owned quarry currently supplies stone and aggregate materials for Council roads and building projects as well as the local construction industry.  It extracts Devonian Flagstone which is highly suited to a range of crushed aggregate products, in particular as roadstone and aggregates, used for producing asphalt for road construction and maintenance, with the quarry being the only active producer of asphalt in Orkney.The activity at the quarry generates an income for the Council which is reinvested to provide and protect some of the vital services we provide in Orkney.The current quarry area is heading towards the end of its use and an expansion would safeguard supply of materials. Current output ranges between , and , tonnes of rock per year andapproved, the ha expansion will release approximately  million tonnes of additional resources, sufficient for another  years of production.Full details are available on the Council website at http:www.orkney.gov.uk Council C long-term-development-of-cursiter-quarry-in-firth.htmPersons wishing to provide comments on the proposed development can do so by writing to AECOM at fraser.blackwood@aecom or by post to Fraser Blackwood, APEX ,  Haymarket Terrace, Edinburgh, EH HD by  February .OIC says that, at this stage, comments made to Aecom are for the purposes of assisting with the scheme design and EIA process and as such are not representations to the Planning Authority. When the planning application is submitted, an opportunity will be given for representations to be made to the Planning Authority.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Black Isle cafes Brexit talk ban raises cash for worthy cause
story: The tongue-in-cheek bid to banish the Brexit blues at Rosemarkie Beach Cafeacute over the festive season saw customers warned theyrsquod face a pound finethey so much as mentioned a word seldom out of the headlines lately.Philip Eley, the long-standing cafeacute manager, explained. ldquoItrsquos just grim. People are so depressed. Folk come to the beach to get away from all those headlines about what the idiots in Westminster are up to, but it only takes one person to mention the B-word to ruin everyone rsquos bacon roll.Customers warmed to the idea and willingly dropped contributions in the bucket during visits to the Black Isle beauty spot.Mr Eleyrsquos partner, Verity Walker, made good on a promise to donate takings from the offbeat bucket collection to the Maggiersquos Highlands cancer care centre at Raigmore Hospital. It was gratefully accepted by fundraising manager David Walker, who is no relation. Ms Walker said: ldquoWe finally got the donations bucket and collecting can to the Maggiersquos Centre at Raigmore ndash they were quite heavy as we kept them on the counter a bit longer and you just kept on giving!ldquoMaggiersquos has helped a number of cafeacute customers and staff. They exist to support those who are affected by cancer, but that includes the families of those diagnosed. If you have never been in, please go and visit, itrsquos a lovely calm space amid the hustle and bustle of Raigmore.Thursday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Black Isle festival issues tongue in cheek invite to ex Oasis star
story: The announcement last week that Noel Gallagher and his High Flying Birds will take to the stage in Inverness on June  was greeted with delight by fans of the multimillion-selling star who shot to fame as the creative force behind Oasis.Less thrilled about the timing of the Bught Park gig, organised by Live in the City and boasting support from Razorlight and Neon Waltz, were the organisers of the Black Isle-based Woodzstock, scheduled to take place on the same date in an outdoor adventure park near Tore, just a few miles from Gallaghers headline-grabbing gig.Woodzstock organisers Charlotte and Dave Elliott admit they were rocked ndash and not in a good way ndash when they learned of the clash. Within hours they rallied with a defiant show must go on plan ndash to invite Gallagher to perform at their intimate venue ahead of his own show in the Highland capital.Charlotte said: "Were excited that big names like Noel Gallaghers High Flying Birds are coming to the Highlands andwe werent holding our festival on the same day we would have loved to see them play. We didnt want to miss him so were inviting Noel to come along and play a few tunes at Woodzstock before his gig in Inverness."She added: "We know it a long shot! Were asking the public to help us by posting online sharing the hashtag #GetNoeltoWoodz"Now entering its third year, Woodzstock has grown year on year with more bands, festival-goers and local businesses, including food producers, artists and performers, sound engineers and local charities, benefiting.Charlotte said: "This year promises to the best Woodzstock yet, we have some fantastic bands already booked, amazing locally sourced food and drink and activities running for the kids. An appearance from Noel would be amazing. We hope our invitation reaches him and he knows our stage will be ready for him".No one from Live in the City was available for comment on the fixture clash. Mr Gallagher could not be reached for comment.Thursday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Businesses gearing up for new adventure festival in Inverness
story: Highland Adventure Fest is expected to take place in Inverness Leisure Centre on Sunday, March .And the event is expected to feature presentations and entertainment from outdoor enthusiasts, as well as demonstrations and live music.The event is being advertised to those who have an interest in outdoor activities such as mountain biking, hiking, and kayaking among others.Festival-goers will be able to try out kit, buy new clothing and equipment, book activities and meet new people with similar interests while enjoying presentations and entertainment on the main stage.The mini festival is being planned by Inverness-based event organisers PLANIT Scotland and will be sponsored by the Glenmore Lodge in Aviemore.Katie Masheter, from PLANIT Scotland, said: ldquoWe are organising the event because the Highlands are quite often seen as a bit of an adventure playground.Miss Masheter went on to say that although they are expecting mostly local people at the event they welcome tourists to come along also, she said: ldquoVisitScotlandrsquos recent tourism conference was placing emphasis on getting the country set-up for an influx of tourists looking for adventure, so what we thought would be great is to pull together an event which brings everyone under one roof.The event is open to all.Thursday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Check your cold weather payment eligibility says Ross MP as temperature plummets
story: Local MP Ian Blackford sayspeople in the Ross, Skye and Lochaber constituency he serves should check eligibility with their nearest Job Centre Plus.This follows an alert of a triggering of the payment for postcode areas IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, between the period    to   .Cold weather payments are made from the Social Fund to certain recipients of Income Support, income-based Jobseekerrsquos Allowance, income-related Employment and Support Allowance, Universal Credit or Pension Credit during periods of very cold weather.To ldquotrigger the payments, the average temperature at a specied weather station must be recorded as, or forecast to be, degC or below for seven consecutive days.The scheme runs from November  to March  each year.The payment is a fixed amount for each week of cold weather. For many years this was set at pound. a week but the LabourGovernment increased the rate to pound a week as a temporary measure for winters - and -. In , the Coalition Government made the pound rate permanent.Payments should be made automatically to those entitled to them there should be no need to make a claim.However concerns have previously been raised that payments can be missed and Mr Blackford believes it is important that people, who believe that they may be eligible follow this through, particularly as the cold weather bites.He said: ldquoWe have been experiencing quite a prolonged period of cold and wet weather in the Highlands and Islands. It is hugely important that anyone eligible for a cold weather payment receives it. It can really make a dference to a vulnerable person or family who is experiencing high heating costs.ldquoThese payments should be made to eligible iniduals automatically, however, in my experience that is not always the case. I would urge anyone who believes that they may be due a payment to contact their nearest Job Centre Plus and get what they are owed.Thursday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Easter Ross Post Offices affected by shops move
story: SHOP closures in two Easter Ross towns could leave the Post Office seeking new premises from which to operate.The changes affect Invergordon and Tain.A Post Office spokesperson said: ldquoWe are aware that our partner CJ Lang who runs Invergordon Post Office, has given us notice and the store will be closing later this year.ldquoThe branch was run independently and while we always work hard to maintain Post Office services, from time to time, branches do temporarily close. When this happens, we always look to restore services as quickly as possible, as we know how important Post Offices are to communities.ldquoWe would like to reassure customers that we are committed to maintaining vital Post Office services for the local community.The spokesman also confirmed that in Tain its partner McCollrsquos Retail Group, which runs the Post Office, has also given notice ldquoand the store will be closing in the spring.He said that branch is also run independently and efforts will be made to restore services as quickly as possible.He said: ldquoWe have had interest from some local retailers who are interested in running this branch but it is very early stages so we are unable to comment further at the moment. ldquoWe would like to reassure customers that we are committed to maintaining vital Post Office services for the local community ndash including banking services like cash withdrawals from high street bank account, bill payments, and of course a wide range of postal services.Thursday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Highland air traffic controllers to be balloted on strike action
story: A BALLOT that could lead to strike action resulting in disruption to flights across the Highlands is due to open next week.The Prospect union confirmed it is going ahead with the ballot of air traffic control members at Highlands and islands airports in a dispute over pay with their employers, Highlands and Islands Airports Ltd .The ballot will run from February  to March  andmembers back industrial action, a series of one-day strikes could start on April  and run throughout the summer.As well as affecting Inverness Airport operations could also be disruptedat Benbecula, Dundee, Kirkwall, Stornoway, Sumburgh and Wick John OGroats.Members are also being askedthey wish to take action short of an all-out strike that could include working to rosters an overtime ban and refusing extensions to airport opening hours for non-medical flights.David Avery, Prospect negotiations officer, said: ldquoMembers do not wish to take this action but have been forced into this position by the refusal of ministers to engage with the issue of air traffic controllersrsquo pay.Hial is owned by the Scottish Government which last week said all staff had been given a pay rise which was a ldquosignicant improvement on previous years.Thursday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies.
